review_title: A great place to work...in many areas
pros: Ohio State is a great place to work in most areas.  The benefits are fantastic and there is a lot of opportunity for growth.  They allow employees to take 10 credit hours per quarter for free which is a terrific benefit just by itself.  Working with students from all over th world is a great way to become more culturally literate.  The university offers so much for employees to take advantage of from sporting events to cultural events, and classes.  There are tons of "lifers" there which says a lot about the work environment.
cons: On the other hand, the university is so large that there are many different climates and cultures.  I loved the first area that I worked in, but the second area was miserable.  In the first area, we had great management, a terrific productive team, and I always wanted to get into work every day to be a part of it.  The second area had good managers but poor directors who either never talked to employees or talked down to them when they did.  Half the staff was on performance improvement in the second area which seems more to be a reflection of the management rather than the employees.

review_title: The case of a IT Support Person
pros:
1.  You get to work with a wide variety of very intellegent people.
2.  Each day is like a box of chocolates, you don't know what you're going to get.
3.  Health Benefits and Retirement Benefits are nice.
4.  College Football Fans can get tickets at a discount.
cons:
1.  Intellegent people are not necessarily "Computer Confortable" so you can end up hand holding some people that have more degrees than a thermometer and think they are better than you because of it.
2.  Each day is like a box of chocolates, you don't know what you're going to get.  
3.  For an institution of higher education the education benefits are not as good as you'd expect,  Only 50% for dependents and while employees can take classes for free there is alot of hoops to jump through to get that approved.
5.  If you are not a Buckeyes fan be prepared for some ribbing.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: The passion and contributing to something great than a wigit or bottom line is amazing.  People truly care about the research, academics and the health care missions of this organization and want to be the best and genuinely want the best for the organization.
cons: There is great change coming in the next 9months to 3 years at the university.  Change is hard and challenging and staff and faculty and students understand that, it feels that often the leadership does not.  They only care about their piece of the pie.  The senior leadership teams need to take the time to learn about areas that perhaps they don't know much about or have experience in to understand the unique challenges those areas have so they can be incorporated and thought about in the bigger picture of the policy, process, work flow changes.  Some areas have unique needs that others don't.  Operating a health care system is completely different than the academic and research has their own completely unique challenges.  How we can be 1 university where it makes sense and have our balance with areas that need more unique work flows.

job_title: Director of Marketing in Columbus, OH
pros: Ohio State provides outstanding benefits -- including the great tuition benefit. They are very pro professional development too, so they are invested in your career advancement. Flexible work environment -- every one worked hard so it wasn't so much about the hours in seats. It was great being surrounded by like-minded individuals who share a common desire to work for a worthy cause -- education!
cons: An employee's experience varies a great deal depending on the Unit you work in (an Administrative Unit vs. a College) and then the type of position you have (classified vs. unclassified). Some Units have more resources than others, which can drastically change your work environment. It is also a bureaucratic institution. If you want a place that is fast-paced, this is not it. You have to be there awhile to start to know the people and the politics and discover the informal power networks and communication channels. Over time, you will know what is going on and will be able to more successfully navigate through the organization.

review_title: The University is great, OCIO leaves a lot to be desired
job_title: Senior Systems Developer in Columbus, OH
pros:
- University environment
- Great benefits, I mean they have their own network/hospital
- Easy to get time off when you need it.
- They prefer to hire from within, and there are lots of different opportunities
cons:
- Middle management is distrustful of employees
- Some employees need to be fired, but it's a state job, so they stick around.
- Funding is sporadic and confusing. Needed projects take forever for funding approval. Quotes from vendors ofter expire due to delays
- Employees who excel are often dragged down to mediocrity due to overwhelming bureaucracy and unreasonable policy
- When sharing concerns with peers, I would often hear "you just care too much"
- Some teams are held to security policys, others are not. Whoever complains the most, gets their way
- Security team (50+ people) play by their own rules, often ignoring change management
- Even the tiniest aspect of the technology stack has an separate employee who's responsible. Trying to change things is met with resistance because "you're invading someone's turf"

pros: The biggest pro about this job was that there was a lot of free time which allows a student to focus on school. I was able to use that time to work on projects, homework, studying, etc., outside of my tasks I needed to finish for the day.
cons: Trouble classrooms are a con. They were hard to manage because you would be called to the same room 2 or 3 times a week. The reason this is a con is because some of the professors would understandably be upset because the classroom malfunctions were inhibiting their ability to do their job. It's a part of the job to provide good customer service here and show empathy as you, the professor, and all of the students in the classroom are waiting on the techs to assist. Most of the time this wouldn't be a problem but every once in a while there would be obvious dissatisfaction from the classroom.

pros: I worked with some incredibly talented and dedicated people. OSU County Extension, Professors, Researchers and colleagues were all fantastic people to work with on a daily basis.
cons:
BEWARE:

* I continuously witnessed and experienced extremely unethical and questionable practices from behind closed doors within the CFAES Marketing & Communications department.

*  Lower than market rate pay for the job that you perform. 1% merit increases for "Meets" and "Exceeds expectations." 

* Office location is Riverwatch tower. Since Riverwatch is owned by a private company, you must pay them and Campus Parc for parking privileges which amount to approximately $1400/year.

* Higher than normal turnover of talent in the CFAES Marketing & Communications Department. 

*  Little to no commitment to service and/or excellence to our internal clients by a "certain few" frontline managers. A few managers would consistently belittle and berate clients and CFAES administrative management in front of the employees. Several clients and professors had even set up alternative methods to skew their way around CFAES Marketing & Communications systems. It got so bad that the college brought in several external consulting firms to document the issues to address ongoing employee and client complaints against the department leadership.

review_title: If you want to work in public service, look elsewhere
pros: Good vacation and sick leave, paid parental leave, scheduling *can* be flexible (varies widely by department)
cons:
Pay is actually pretty poor for public sector work, and raises are very poor
Medical benefits are okay, but again, not up to snuff compared to other public sector jobs
Very top-heavy bureacracy

review_title: Don't do it.  This place will drive you crazy.
pros: Access to season football tickets after 3 years of employment.  Free education.  In my particular group (IT), they were super flexible with schedules and time off, but it depends on the area you work for.
cons: Incompetent coworkers and managers; unmanaged mentally ill coworkers; inefficiencies; lack of professionalism.  Politics.  Low pay that it typical of higher education.  Depending on your field, advancement opportunities are very limited.  Annual salary increases are minimal at best.  Often looking to cut budgets - nearly every year.  When you speak with employees, they all measure their time there as "I have XX years until retirement."  That is the only thing that gets them through the days on their jobs.  Very sad.  I never saw such an enormous lack of professionalism in one place.  Seriously.  Avoid like the plague!

pros: OSU is very diverse. It has many different departments which are all run completely independent.  My department has a good work/life balance.  Hours are usually flexible, as it's typically up to your manager.  There are many benefits like the ability to get sporting tickets at a discounted rate.  Benefits, while having gone up quite a bit over the years, are now very similar to most large corporations.  Annual raises are the norm however there is very rarely a bonus structure.  It is typically a very "safe" place to work.  Either your job has to be eliminated or you have to really screw up to get fired.
cons: It's in Columbus, OH.  Because you have to really screw up to get fired, if you are a good employee, you can get stuck picking up the slack for someone else.  Pay can be a little lower than large corporate, but they have been doing much better about that.

review_title: Ok if You're Only Interested in Good Benefits
pros:
Football tickets (if you're into the Buckeyes) after you've earned enough tenure to purchase them
Great benefits, especially tuition (for employees and dependents is awesome!)
cons:
Horrible, horrible parking
No career development for staff
No succession planning for staff
Very, very difficult to advance to another job title or career period unless you know someone who can get you into a different position
Stagnant environment; many people become "lifers" just waiting to retire
Pay is very low and not competitive compared to market, due to fact that it's a state institution and budget cuts are always occurring; merit increases are insulting
The only people who prosper are the faculty and high level executive/administrative individuals

review_title: Graduate school is not for everyone.
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: I will be receiving a post graduate degree from a will known university.
cons: Graduate research associates are not students and are not staff.  As a senior graduate student, taking classes is frowned upon.  Despite the fact that you work well over 40 hours a week your contract is for 20 hours a week making you part time staff.  As part time staff you are not entitled to any benefits that apply to employees of the Ohio State University.  GRAs are compensated for far less than what they are worth had they taken a job outside of academia and are rarely recognized for their contributions.  GRAs are expected to give up their life and free time to work in the lab.

pros: Offers great benefits for full-time employees, including tuition assistance (although there is some out of pocket). You're able to network and meet with many different types of people in all sorts of positions, if you put in the effort. The president of the university seems focused on improving the student experience and affordability.
cons: Leadership within colleges and units can be shaky and not set great examples. There are plenty of double standards all over the campus. One major con is that not often are the steps taken to improve the workplace and culture. It's typically approached by avoiding the disruptive employees and allowing quality employees to move on to other workplaces within the university. It can also be extremely hard to move within the university - it depends on who you know. Work life balance various from department and is not a guarantee.

review_title: Mostly well-meaning people in a cluttered bureaucracy
pros: Most colleagues are genuinely pleasant people, low cost of living.
cons: There's a cultural tendency here to not work to make things easier for other people. For example, if you want to find a large format printer, you're going to need to refer to an old website created by a frustrated student because that's the only public listing. None of the IT people or logistics people would set that up because it's not something their boss has told them to do. Diversity seems higher at the top than the bottom, and the method for increasing diversity at the bottom is self-sabotaging because it doesn't focus on getting buy-in from the faculty.

review_title: Great benefits for graduate school, Salary at higher end of grad school range.
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: The health benefits for grad students are great, better than those for their employees in my opinion. There are also a lot of career support mechanisms in place for students. The campus is beautiful. There affordable is family housing which is great. I also like the diverse international community on campus.
cons: There is no official vacation time for graduate students and post-docs, this is left to the discretion of your advisor/boss. Therefore time-off is irregular and differs from student to student, which I believe is not fair. There is also no set salary and salary increase mechanism for post-docs.

job_title: Field Station Assistant in Put in Bay, OH
pros:
You will learn a lot as a Field Station Assistant. If you love teaching kids grades 5th-12th about science then this is the job for you! We teach classes on a boat, outside, and in the classroom. Various classes are herpetology, fish dissection, climate change, invertebrates, etc. You get to live on an island which is an awesome experience. You learn how to drive many different types of boats, how to trawl, go wetland sampling, and take care of different herps.
Theres so many opportunities from this job. 

You get plenty of hours, free meals, and free rent!!!!

You get 24 hour access to Put In Bay, you become a local here. 

You get to be outside. 

Management is very nice and friendly. They have your back.
cons:
Golf carts.... 
tourists take over your island.
long hours,
teach for half the season the rest is maintenance work like pulling weeds, racking rocks, painting, recycling off the island.

review_title: Great part time job for students
pros:
Employee meal every 4 hour shift
Full-time managers are friendly and relaxed
Co-workers are willing to help; it's a team environment
Fairly flexible scheduling
Easily accessible lockers for while you're at work
cons:
Not allowed to take tips
Late-night shifts tend to cater to a high percentage of inebriated customers and walking home afterwards is not always safe.
Parking a serious issue.

review_title: Great University Toxic Work Culture and Management
job_title: Senior Director of Development in Columbus, OH
pros: Loved being a part of an awesome university in a vibrant city.  Opportunities to further your education for free or very inexpensive. Super place for college students to attend college
cons: Toxic work environment, significant salary inequality between male and female employees with the exact same positions egregious. C-suite managers receive bonus structure even though they already made $300K - $500K. No career coaching or opportunity to move up internally.  many departments at the university  will not promote from within. University President is grossly overpaid at $1 million a year plus bonus.

pros: Great opportunity to get OSU on your resume but just like everywhere else, totally depends on who your manager is and the team you work with. The retirement benefits are pretty amazing if you're willing to stick with them for a long time. Other benefits are fine - not as robust as they used to be. Senior leadership is very communicative and transparent. The president of the university is very compassionate and obviously well suited for his position.
cons: Depending on the department you are hired in, it seems your pay can be unequal to other departments pay with the same job title and responsibilities. I receive very low pay compared to my counterparts in other departments, however it was really good experience to get under my belt.

review_title: Nice place to work if you don't mind being underpaid
job_title: Research Associate I B/H in Columbus, OH
pros:
Pleasant campus environment, and it is stimulating to have students and grad students around exploring new areas of research and keeping things lively.
Benefits are good. Work schedule is flexible and allows you time for a life outside of work. Got to work on some cool projects.
cons:
It would be good to have more communication between supervisors and employees. The pay is dismal for the position ranking, and there isn't much opportunity for advancement. It's been two years without a raise, and colleagues with the same level of experience hired after me are being paid higher wages.
Parking is expensive if you want to park anywhere near you building.

job_title: Psychiatric Care Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Free tuition and ability to say you work at Ohio State.
cons:
Extremely unsafe atmosphere, no metal detectors, staff not abiding by policies and not checking patients upon arrival. While working with there had countless death threats by patients who could watch you walk to your car and know where you park and your car etc. Also had two patients with knives on the floor threatening to hurt staff (knives should've been caught by staff skin checks and clothing checks). Not enough staff to keep others safe. I was once cornered and was told to "run" rather than other staff choosing to assist me.

Horrible work environment, tons of call offs, high expectations with minimal support.

Most patients were admitted simply because beds needed filled to bring in more money, most of the really ill patients did not receive proper care, were turned away, or sent home too early and sometimes died shortly after (overdoses etc).

Also- $50 parking pass per month in a lot that floods and totals cars overtime it rains more than a sprinkle.

review_title: Ohio State is a good academic institution, and overall it is a good place to work.
pros: Ohio State University has outstanding facilities and for the most part excellent faculty.  With its midwest location, Ohio State employees enjoy a relatively low cost of living with a stable housing market.  Ohio State is a nationally recognized employer/university.  Overall, Ohio State University is a great place to work.  No place is perfect, but I'd rank Ohio State as one of the better places I've worked.
cons: As with any large university or business, there is too much bureaucracy at Ohio State University.  Another weakness, at the college level, is poor communications from leadership.  Also there is currently a funding crisis in academia under the current U.S. Governement Administration (i.e., Bush).

review_title: Too Much Work for Little Pay
job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in Columbus, OH
pros: Their benefits & Helping patients get through the most difficult time in their lives, which in some cases may be the end of their lives is rewarding.
cons: This job definitely does not pay enough, it is physically and emotionally draining, and the patient to PCA ratio should be reduced, especially when they have patients with more complex health issues, and there should be and extra stipend (more money) for preparing someone after they have passed on, and a choice should be given to do that or not, and blood draws should be done by an actual phlebotomists that have special training - not PCA's.

pros: There was a panel of current staff members in the interview and all of them got to ask questions. What I enjoyed about this type of interview was that it showed the department values a team environment. Each employee got to be part of the hiring process because they want to ensure the department is bringing someone the entire team would want to work with on a day to day basis. As an interviewee, I was able to ask different people about their various roles and truly learn about the culture.
cons: 6 people interviewing one person is a lot! I thrive on people interaction, but even I can admit this style of interviewing was a little intimidating. As an interviewee, you are now trying to sell yourself to more than one person that you are the best for the job and that can be difficult.

review_title: Ohio State- A Great Place To Work
pros:
Many opportunities for education and professional development.
Course work both related to the job as well as outside of job duties is funded.
Ohio State offers services for students,faculty, and staff for career development and exploration
The medical plan offered through Ohio State is one of the best in the country.
cons: Salaries across the university need to be more equitable. Salaries for staff as well as faculty tend to vary with each department.  While this tends to be the case in other universities as well, it needs to be considered for Ohio State Staff as well.

job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Columbus, OH
pros: Benefits and retirement. Work with some employees who truly care for the University.
cons: On the contrary, some employees stay on the same role for long (10+ years) on the same position. The side effect to this is, they know it all and it must be done like that or else you are dragged into the politics side. Its a very political world, at the expense of tax money, etc. Worked on the Enterprise Project - which has not been managed properly- hint the extremely and unusually high turnover. I would ask some very detailed questions during the interview process. For this type of career, I recommend else where given your potential to grow and challenge yourself - which is part of a BA career path.

pros: health, retirement, and education benefits are significant; the university as a whole has a good reputation; stability;  perks
cons: inconsistent communications;  undefined roles and responsibilities;  ineffective tactical processes;  sick time policy rewards "slackers";  hiring practices and processes for staff needs considerable improvement to attract and retain long-term performers

review_title: Good benefits and work environment, relatively lower pay
pros: If you work full-time but your schedule is flexible (which it very well may be here) you can take classes tuition-free. Central campus is a great work setting if you don't mind the throngs of students when school is in session. Housing in Columbus is super affordable, with a variety of good quality neighborhoods to choose from.
cons: For non-faculty jobs pay is low compared to the equivalent in the private sector, which is a condition not unique to Ohio State. Parking is challenging here, and a central campus permit will cost you over $800 a year. Bicycle commuters are common, perhaps because of this fact.

pros: Large vibrant campus, Columbus is a great city.
cons: Campus parking will cost 1K per year,  Health care plans for faculty are poor and getting worse every year -compared to what other universities offer. It will  be expensive to use and you may find yourself in situations where you are reluctant to go to ER or seek the specialist care you need as a result.  University is too large,  resulting in some disorganization and poor decision making at the administrative level where too many key decisions are made.  Retirement savings plan is also poor in comparison to other universities. You wouldn't think so, but all things considered, it takes a significant chunk out of your bottom line and hopes you may have for an overall good quality of life. Weigh it all out very carefully when you negotiate.

pros: University employees receive decent benefits and work/life balance is okay.
cons: The department I worked in was mismanaged in terms of personnel and finances. Everything revolved around the director, and people in management positions had no management experience or sensibility and were paid way too much to do so little - there was an enormous pay disparity from top to bottom. Opportunities for advancement were very limited depending on your work area, and based on favoritism in a few instances. Some senior management involved in misusing university resources and other ethics violations, and the university human resources does what it can to mitigate and cover up without proper investigation or consideration of staff complaints.

pros: Have a very talented group in the maintenance department. Managers are very nice and will attempt to help you in any way they can. Health insurance is low cost.
cons: No career ladders, way below competitive pay, will not pay tuition to other schools that offer courses that would be beneficial to the maintenance department, although have things set in place where if you are part of the nursing staff they will pay for other schools. Will only pay for schooling at the school that they own, which happens to not offer hardly anything that the maintenance department would benefit their same career paths with.

pros: Working for OSU is a pretty prestigious attribute to put on your resume. Also, there are a lot of people who are involved in industry, so it is also a good way to network and make connections. Administratively speaking, I can't say I've had any problems.
cons: There are a lot of people so it is easy to feel like a number. Some professors can be stuck up and may talk down to you if you do not have a PhD after your name. Gordon Gee only looks out for the profit of the university and not the best interests of the students, faculty and staff.

pros: I was in the physics department of OSU. Everyone I met was really nice at the personal level, however there are some major problems with this university in general.
cons:
The physics department harbors an environment of no work-life balance. Calling folks on the cell phone at random off-work hours including weekend is considered normal. Communication is often not clear, leading to undefined expectations.

In addition, there are issues revolving around sexual harassment that OSU in general is actively trying to hide. There are stories that you hear within the department but does not really get out because no one trust OSU to do anything meaningful about the situation. This all led to a very stressful/unsafe and unproductive work environment.

job_title: Research Scientist & Laser Capture Molecular Core Lab Manager in Columbus, OH
pros:
The suburbs surrounding Columbus OH are nice places to raise a family.
There may be other nice things to say about OSU but I don't remember them.
cons:
Unless you are white and male you will not get promoted or receive raises on a regular basis. This is especially true for the Medical Center.
Postdocs, who are amongst the lowest paid employees, have to pay the same outrageous parking fee as a full professor who makes at least 5 times as much. 
They tried to run the Medical Center like a corporation complete with outrageous pay packages for the top execs. Of course it didn't work!
Nepotism triumphs over competence any given day.

review_title: Not a good work environment for professionals. Most positive reviews on here are from student employees.
pros: Retirement benefits are good. Working in windowless office spaces helps humanity evolve into vampires which is cool if you’re into that.
cons: Hostile supervisory structures throughout the university. I hear time and time again and see it myself, people are consistently treated poorly by their supervisors. People leaving jobs is more often a case of people leaving managers rather than jobs. OSU definitely has this problem in regards to turnover. When moving around jobs within the university, everywhere requires speaking with your current supervisor as a reference. All this does is prevent people from speaking out about poor working environments created by managers, because everyone knows not to rock the boat or you hurt your chances of getting another job at the university.

review_title: College of Public Health:  Small, impactful College within a R1 university
pros: The College of Public Health is a small interdisciplinary college within a very large university.  There is a reasonable balance of teaching (3 courses per academic year), research and service duties.  Lots of opportunities to have collaborations within the College and the larger University environment.  Given the shrinking of federal grant opportunities, the expectation of extramural funding is not overly unrealistic.
cons: There is a pending change in the Administration, which brings some uncertainty.  Yet the presence of strong Division Chairs and other administrators will likely support the College as a new Dean takes over the vision for the future.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: For most professors, there is a lot of flexibility in your work hours and what you research.  It really is up to you.  Also, tuition is free, so can take as many classes as you want.   There is also a lot of great food in the city.
cons: Most professors see you as little more than their personal workers.  Some have ridiculous expectations like working 6-7 days a week, holidays, things like that.   You are at their mercy to graduate and leave.  That really depends on your professor, most foreign ones act like this.  There are also lots of problems with the school in general.  Other things include parking costs and overselling the parking lots, having preferred vendors that are horrible, slow ordering of supplies.

review_title: Postdoc Researcher at The Ohio State University
pros:
This is the largest university in America with pretty good academic environment.  It offers plenty of resources for scientific research.  People can find good career development opportunities through its wide connections to both national institute and industries.  
The campus is located in Columbus, capital of the state of Ohio.  It is a nice city to live.  The size is just perfect satisfying most people's demand while staying away from the metropolitan annoying issues, such as violence and traffic jams.  Living cost is really low, maybe the lowest among the similar size city and comparable small towns.
cons: Not a tourist attraction, but there are a lot of famous places within driving distance.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Ohio State offers the best of the traditional Research I University - Midwestern culture, consistent focus on academic excellence.  The compensation when compared to peer institutions (Big 10 schools) is quite reasonable.  Treatment of graduate students varies greatly by department, but I have found that the University as a whole provides numerous opportunities for graduate students to prepare themselves for future research careers.
cons: As with any public university, the pressure of the state and federal budget on the institution is continual.  There is significant concern that salaries for faculty and graduate student stipends will not be competitive with private institutions and industry.

review_title: Working at OSU was worthwhile (people, experiences) as well as fulfilling (higher education, obtaining Master's Degree).
pros: OSU has great benefits for graduate students as well as full time employees. OSU is also committed to helping you get the most out of your education as well as employment.  To be such a large school, it has a very small feel.
cons: It's hard to navigate the university if you are new, and don't fully know what it is you want to accomplish.

review_title: Decent graduate school, but you will feel like a statistic
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Diverse graduate student population, heavily tending toward international students.
- Very diverse range of course offerings, so you can take a class in pretty much anything.
- Great library system with a lot of perks to help you find what you need.
- Located in a great city.
cons:
- Undergraduates are very hit-or-miss on whether they want to apply themselves.
- Advisors are ill-equipped to efficiently deal with large numbers of advisees, which happens in larger departments.
- Campus is always under construction, so expect delays when commuting.
- Since it is such a large school, it will often feel like you're a statistic instead of a living, breathing human being.
- It is VERY difficult to find information throughout the university.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: - Facilities are modern (but falling apart because of maintenance budget cuts)
cons:
- Abusive actions by staff and faculty towards their graduate advisees (have experienced or heard of everything from sexual misconduct, yelling at students all the way to firing without cause)
- Abusive administrators that make sure their kids enrolled at Ohio State are taken care of first
- Abusive family of administrators that show up at the workplace to demand that their needs are put at the fore before everyone else
- No one knows answers - it's disturbing to call the same department on the same day and receive 2 different answers to the same question
- This place is huge and it feels overwhelming, and I am currently looking to be employed elsewhere

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Relaxed environment. Great co-workers. Supportive mentors. Easy to find great living near work. And I have access to all the technical tools that I need. They've got it all.
cons:
They pay feels a little low commensurate with experience, but it is not out of the ordinary for 
the university at large

The students can be a mixed bag. It is an open university so that is to be expected. Most are pretty good though.

review_title: A brief overview of the Ohio State University.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: The best reason to work at the Ohio State University is the extensive academic resources available.  The quantity and quality of knowledgeable individuals supports the high level of research performed.  The additional benefits of a working here are related to the size of the university (i.e. an amazing fitness center, community outreach progams, libraries, etc).  My experience here has been positive largely due to the quality of my research adviser.
cons: The immense size can be overwhelming.   You have to actively work to find a place for yourself within the academic community.  The location of the university can be undesirable, however, Columbus offers a number of good communities.

review_title: They would sell our organs on the black market if they could
pros:
good health benefits coverage 
smattering of non-evil co-workers
our patients are dogs, cats, etc
cons:
Your value here is determined by who you are friends with/who dislikes you versus your actual competence and quality of work. Systematic disrespect and emotional abuse. You will not be treated like a person unless you are a spy and tattle on your co-workers 
LOADS OF UNPROFESSIONAL, UNEDUCATED CO-WORKERS. LOADS 
Toxic workplace; I often wish for a moderate car crash on the way in and relish having the flu, so I can miss a day. 
4th year veterinary students treated like crap. General lack of respect, rudeness, and impatience toward generally good, smart, soon-to-be doctors. I often see students crying, going without meals, or fearful or 'failure' to the point of neglecting bathroom breaks.

review_title: Not terrible as graduate student working conditions go...
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
Better treatment of graduate employees than I've seen at other institutions
Departmental teaching support can vary, but in many humanities departments, teaching supervisors offer great support
Quarter system teaching load is reasonable
cons:
Biased treatment of "favorite" graduate student employees
No summer employment in many departments
Health benefits not extended for summer months without out-of-pocket payment from unemployed GTAs
Teaching experience outside of academia is not valued
Unclear picture of what will happen to GTAships on semester system

review_title: Department of Recreational Sports, Member Services Crew Chief.
job_title: Member Services Crew Chief in Columbus, MO
pros: Very helpful in knowing student body especially you are into careers such as student development, sports management. A lot of room for you to learn and develop leadership skills. Professional staff in the department are extremely friendly and helpful. The university focuses on people and environment, and you can see that everywhere on campus.
cons: The main recreation center on campus (RPAC) is the largest college facility in the nation. The facility capacity is tremendous, and the issues and emergencies you encounter every single day might be intimidating and overwhelming. It does take some time to adapt to the environment there.

pros:
good hr policies for new mothers
financially well run
very spirited; people love OSU
low cost of living in Columbus
great gym and campus union, ditto new library.
they do a good job removing snow
great activities to attend after work, good tuition remission. 
President Gee lives his job and the students love him.
cons:
It's a massive organization. You can work in a large division and not really know anyone outside your department. 
Unusual jobs are created for people - either to slowly push them out, or to keep them at the institution so they don't leave. 
A bit corporate in the Executive side of the house, wasted millions on a "culture changing" seminar/retreat which yielded little except some books for kids and emails that are deleted.

review_title: Students are treated as numbers and staff are treated as disposable
pros: Ohio State has great benefits and staff members can sign up for up to 10 credit hours each semester (free).  There are a lot a great little resources on OSU's campus-- there's a campus pharmacy, an incentive program for doing your yearly health screening, a discounted weight watchers program-- lots of little nuggets of benefits.
cons: I would argue that most non-executive staff members are severely underpaid at Ohio State; perhaps because of the high number of people seeking to work at OSU (supply & demand, right?). Further, staff members do not seem really interested in serving students.  They are there for the benefits and football tickets.  This was my perception, at least. Oh, parking permit prices are insane and get worse every year.

pros:
-Generally smart people
-Tons of brand loyalty among students, staff, faculty, which means the workforce is pretty dedicated to the organization
-Low expectations for job performance means a decent worker can look like a genius if they put in a little hustle (but, see below)
cons:
-Low expectations of job performance means most people live by the "close enough for government work" mantra
-Not very diverse
-Low pay
-State government isn't willing to put resources into even the low-hanging fruit that would help its employees be exponentially more efficient and effective

pros: They have good benefits. Other than that don't leave your current job to go to osu!
cons: What is not wrong with this university. Cross contamination. Using dirty instruments on a different patient! They put their own job over doing what is right. They don't put money into their employees. The pay is awful!

review_title: This is a place full of opportunities, excellent research department, good communication.
pros: OSU is an excellent place to be exposed to a variety of cultures, there is high emphasis placed on understanding diversity. Cancer research in collaboration with James Cancer is excellent, there are many exciting clinical trials going on. The benefits are decent. There are a lot of resources for employees to advance in their field as well as to do their job correctly.
cons: Postdoctoral researcher salaries are below NIH recommendations but the expectations are very high. Some research buildings are not updated, equipment in some laboratories is ancient. Parking is limited and very expensive (same cost for a postdoc with $35,000 as for a doctor with $100,000).

review_title: Good working environment, opportunity for growth
pros: There is a lot of room for promotion and taking on more responsibilities.  Upper management is generally supportive of projects to increase organization and efficiency, and staff members are given a free hand to pursue such projects.  Pleasant and cooperative coworkers and little in-fighting.
cons: Working within the academic bureaucracy can be challenging, and rules and procedures seemingly change without notice.  The unwritten staff "tenure" policy can make it challenging to get rid of seriously underperforming staff members, making more responsible employees pick up the slack.

pros: Working with work pool is an incredible experience and enjoy every opportunity that I had during my time at the University. I was able to learn new things everyday and was extremely fortunate to be able to work there. In addition, it is one of the highest paid positions in the University and with easy hours.
cons: Work really comes and goes with never a consistent work schedule which is a major flaw to working there, because one month you would be working 20-40 hours a week and the next month after finishing a project you would be lucky to be getting 10 hours a week

review_title: Great people, Great Benefits, Great job... but not very changable
pros:
Amazing, intelligent and down-to earth friendly people
Great healthcare benefit (student perspective)
Discounted tuition, as well as employer who wants you to continue your education
cons: tradition rules-- you come across people who have been in their job for 30+ years and will stay there until they kick the bucket. Change is hard to come by, and if it is, it's probably not going to be good. The centralization of processing is completely insane and not streamlined and not thought out. Also getting rid of problem employees is neigh impossible, leaving poorly trained people in positions where someone could come in and make everything efficient.

job_title: Patient Revenue Cyclist in Columbus, OH
pros: Benefits, but  a lot of other places that are fully staffed have great benefits also.
cons: The medical referrals are constantly coming in and are never follow up with in a timely manner due to consistently being understaffed and taking a high volume of inbound calls.   Management doesn't seem to understand that offering overtime isn't a permanent solution,  a full staff, however is a solution.  I've watched management try to suck as much out of the patient customer service employees without additional pay or adding a full staff.

review_title: Tuition Covered but No Stipend Increase based on Seniority
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: GRA position provide good financial support for my PhD journey. It also provides benefits if you meet certain standards such as free 3-credit hours in Summer Semester after your full year GRA employment, although it is not actually free because your funding source actually pays for it. The whole experience really depends on who actually hire you such as the professor you work for and the grant project.
cons: GRA salary is called stipend. The stipend varies across colleges or departments. GRAs in my college, Education and Human Ecology, are paid less than some other colleges such as Engineering. Also, your stipend won't increase no matter if you passed qualification, candidacy, or whatever.

review_title: Broad view of the the Ohio State University
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: There is a lot of intellectual freedom to explore your career and your goals within the university. There is an excellent breadth of opportunities for cross-disciplinary study at OSU.
cons: Universities typically pay less than positions outside in industry, but this is true across the board. The new policy of allowing graduate students to only register for 3 credits has eliminated one of the best perks for graduate students--free elective classes. This is a new policy that may change once the administration realizes the full impact of its policies.

review_title: Very laid back and comfortable environment
pros: Very laid back environment. Many paid off holidays.  Management is very good. Great environment. You get to participate in many activities. If you have kids, they get to go to school almost for free. (i think osu pays for the bigger part of tution) .  You get free or almost free access to a state of the art recreation facility. They also have great bonuses, and since its civil service job, if you work for 20 years for them you get AWESOME retirment package.  Good luck.
cons: Maybe pay could be a little better. However, u get less money and less stress. So, its up to you what you value more.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Tuition payment, flexible hours, opportunity to network and do research. Helping students is gratifying and feeling appreciated really contributes to job satisfaction. Schedules are extremely flexible as long as 20 hours is worked within the week.
cons: The monthly stipend sounds like a lot but really is too low to sustain a reasonable lifestyle for a graduate student. Getting paid monthly is hard on keeping a budget. Sometimes there is not enough work to be completed, and during other quarters the work is overwhelming when teaching a class while also taking classes yourself. Human resources and other supportive job services a lot of times are incompetent.

review_title: Nice place to complete your graduate degree
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Freedom to work on the projects you want. My advisor was very open to seeing through the projects I wanted, others, I cant say the same thing. You are pretty much free to rule your own roost as long as you keep up with your work and don't slack off.
cons: Your pay will never increase. This is a government organization therefore you are dictated by state law. But that being said its just a university and you will come out with your degree getting paid a lot more than you would expect. Campus life is very fun as long as you can stand it.

review_title: Residence Life makes such a big institution so intimate
pros: Ohio State University is expansive and offers so many opportunities for growth and connection. While I did work in residence life, I made connections with Resident Directors, Area Directors, Graduate Assistants, Resident Managers, Resident Advisors and Office Assistants all over the entire campus. Residence Life has given me the opportunity to make those connections. Furthermore, OSU Residence Life fostered my connection with the University and the city of Columbus. I am proud of my employment and experience at Ohio State University.
cons: In Residence Life, the days are long, but you have to expect that you can and most likely will receive a call in the middle of the night.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: I can only say from my experience in the College of Engineering, but the GRA positions are fantastic and expose you to a lot of unique and challenging opportunities while fulfilling your research requirements. Having all tuition and fees paid for is a huge benefit (including optional student health insurance) and the stipend is competitive with other major research universities. I was even reimbursed for mileage since my position was stationed 50 miles from campus and I had to commute there 2-3 times a week.
cons: Parking on campus can be a bit of a challenge during peak hours. CampusParc is ruthless when it comes to parking enforcement, so make sure you follow their rules.

pros: The best part about working for OSU are the benefits, particularly the educational ones.  You can often get flex time to take classes.
cons: As far as a career in IT goes, it is very limited.  The raises are miniscule and there is not much room for advancement.  OSU tends to be management-heavy.  There is a 1:1 director/associate director to developer ratio in my department.  Management's philosophy is that "you don't need a technical background to manage technology."

review_title: Great First Job Out of College
job_title: Instructional Aids Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Flexible schedule, can work from home, professional development funds available, open and relaxed atmosphere, exposure to a variety of people of all ages, backgrounds, and expertise, ability to set your own schedule, directly on many bus routes and major bike path for an easy commute.
cons: Can easily become distracted by the number of events and initiatives occurring on campus, University initiatives are often too vague and unguided, university is privatizing everything, parking passes are expensive, driving on main campus is a nightmare, campus essentially shuts down for all major sporting events

review_title: A great place to work...with a few issues
pros:
- Rewarding jobs
- OPERS retirement plan
- Good paid leave programs, including parental leave
cons:
- Salaries are mostly flat-lined. Raises of <1% per year aren't unexpected.
- Performance reviews don't translate to higher Salaries
- Lack of defined career path for professional staff

review_title: Amazing place to start a teaching career
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU provides a competitive compensation package for graduate students along with a fairly light teaching load, which gives you plenty of time for your own studies. At the same time, you get a ton of support for your teaching. There's always someone to provide you with advice, feedback, etc.
cons: The only downsides of teach First-Year Composition at Ohio State are the same downsides that I imagine come with teaching First-Year Composition at any school -- student apathy, student whining, etc.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Very nice atmosphere, helpful superiors in anything you might need them for, very accommodating to student life and class schedules, always pushed to do the best that you can in anything they ask you to do.
cons: The hours weren't the best, because they have so many student employees they don't always give you the hours that you ask for. They can also let mistakes slide a bit too easily at times, which can be helpful when it's you, but very annoying when it's coworkers.

pros: Great benefits (both health and education), good people, good as an entry level job
cons: If you are not interested in Academics, do not apply to work in an academic office.  There is too much politics for my taste and the work loads are very uneven.  Compensation (salary) wise is not super great for the requirements needed in order to be even interview for the job.  There is not a lot of room for growth and movement within the department, one would need to look at other departments if they want to move up.

review_title: Getting paid to get my Ph.d.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Working towards my Ph.d. in mechanical engineering and getting paid for my dissertation research.  The work is self paced and and interesting.  Interesting funding opportunities including GRA, GTA, fellowship, and Instructor.
cons: The pay is far below industry for masters in mechanical engineering. Very little recognition for day to day work or publications. Only real recognition for students who win specific awards or who reach end the end of their degree.

pros: The retirement plan and insurance are pretty great. Also, there are lots of perks, like access to the gym, which features two Olympic sized swimming pools, saunas, hot tubs, climbing walls, and an indoor track, plus great group classes at a way better value than you'd find outside.
cons: The salaries are low, you don't get merit raises (in fact "leadership" will go out of their way to make sure you don't, just to keep the budget down) and the whole place is going the way of corporate universities everywhere--maximum profit, minimum instruction, minimum quality, and pretty crappy treatment of employees. My gynecologist is through the school health insurance and she recently told me that literally all of her patients are women who work at OSU and all of them are overworked and underpaid, so much so that it's affecting their health.

review_title: OSU Program Manager - sometimes meaningful work, sometimes stuck
pros: Great health benefits. OSU Buckeyes culture
cons: Not much opportunity to advance in this career. Be prepared to sit it out, or change from College to College, department to department. I basically did the same job for 15 years, but it kep t getting HARDER to do. OSU is not hiring much due to COVID. Not all of the jobs available are reported online. You have to know someone to find the others.

pros: The Ohio State University is among the top 12 U.S. public research universities and 3rd among all universities in industry-sponsored research (National Science Foundation). [33] It is also named as one of the most innovative universities in the nation (U.S. News & World Report) and in the world (Reuters))
cons: Ohio State became the first university in Ohio to be extended membership into the Association of American Universities, and remains the only public university in Ohio among the organization's 60 members. The Public Ivies: America's Flagship Public Universities (2000) by Howard and Matthew Greene listed Ohio State as one of a select number of public universities offering the highest educational quality.

pros: Access to newer technologies, open to new ideas, scale of a large enterprise without restrictions that come with retail or corporate environments. You'll gain a lot of experience with a wide range of different hardware and software. Always something to do.
cons: Extremely large organization with a tendency to fail at communication. Deans that are wasteful with money. Reduced IT budgets in certain places where it tends to matter a lot much later on when things break. Management doesn't seem to have a clue what it is that network engineers do.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: The BME department is dedicated to education. The BME department center their courses to integrate labs and core curriculum  unique to each student's interests. Of all the engineering departments I have worked in, this one has been the best.
cons: With the field being new, the challenge with pursuing a degree in BME is the minimal job opportunities. The department has taken steps to integrate more corporate senior design projects to improve the graduate to full time position timeline.

pros: Benefits!!!!! They have great health,  dental and vision insurance.  They also give matching contributions to your retirement fund.  As an employee, you can also get some great discounts on local events such as Columbus Crew games (MLS). Smoking is also prohibited on university ground.
cons: The parking is $74/mo. The administration is ridiculously inefficient. You need to physically walk up to the administration rep to check the current status ofor anything requiring administration. they constantly lose or misplace paperwork.  Faculty have the tendency to look down on you, seeing you as a grunt.

review_title: Proud to be a former Buckeye.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros:
The benefits and availability and access to all the various facilities and resources the University has to offer are great. 
Each department sort of exists in it's own little vacuum and is left to manage its own day-to-day operations.
cons: Each department sort of exists in it's own little vacuum, so differing departments (HR, Stores/receiving, IT, etc.) are often not aware of how changes to one's protocols affects the ability of others to work. The left hand rarely knows what the right hand is doing.

review_title: Awful place to work if you aren't in the right field.
pros: Health insurance, sick time and holidays.
cons: If you work in a science field and do not have a PhD you are treated like a second class citizen. Favoritism, nepotism and abuse ran rampant in the department where I worked and the supervisor was a massively dishonest sycophant who would throw any of us staff members under the bus to kiss up to the dept chair. Active discrimination by supervisor on annual reviews directed toward me while other staff members did far less work and falsified their time cards since there was not an actual time clock. No advancement opportunities and no professional development in the department. Abysmal place to work with supervisor retaliation for taking time off during semester.

review_title: Great opportunity to work with students, and expand skill set
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
personal interactions
program coordinators are open to new ideas and change
supportive leaders if you have a good idea and some energy to invest in it
lots to do on campus and in the city
good facilities
can take classes in anything
cons:
middle to upper management can be detached
budgets are tight and always shrinking
can work people too hard for lack of budget for new positions
be prepared to pursue your ideas to the very end with only verbal support - no time or money committed

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Graduate schools are becoming among the nation's best for public institutions.  Quality of faculty is continually improving and the school is well run.  Stipends are generous when considering the relatively low cost of living in Columbus.
cons: Certain graduate labs are located on West Campus, away from the action of main campus.  This detracts somewhat from the quality of social life while a graduate student and can complicate attendance of lectures on main campus.  Parking is a nightmare on main campus.

review_title: Good Place to Work if you have a PhD
pros: Benefits package; affinity discounts for car insurance, cars, cable, and other stuff you use; employees who can't use tix to some sporting events will advertise via OSU email and either give or charge face-value.
cons: Too many people doing too many things with little-to-no communication. No training. If you don't have a PhD, you are not treated with consideration and professionalism.

pros: Good spirited and energy employer with numerous opportunities to learn more. Most staff I have encountered are kind and helpful which makes work a little more enjoyable.
cons: Very hard to advance within the University, especially within your department. As with most employers changes often are made from the top without truly considering the impact it will have on the staff actually performing the duty.

pros:
Great environment to work in for current students at Ohio State University, specifically the Fisher College of Business. 
Flexible hours 
Interesting studies
cons:
There are no cons to working in the Behavioral Lab. I enjoyed my time as a research assistant for the year that I worked there. 
The lab manager is great and so are the researching grad students and professors.

job_title: A/V Shift Lead in Columbus, OH
pros: My employer is very kind, and the job allows for VERY flexible work hours. Work is stimulating as well as allowing for a lot of downtime for doing schoolwork on the off hours.
cons: The training for becoming a tech was very lacking; though they keep with a policy of learning on the job, I think formal training should be allowed for students who desire to move up in the ranks as fast as possible.

review_title: Good Environment and Bosses, Work Itself was OK
pros: Supervisors were very understanding about classes and my schedule, work itself was never too hard or fast-paced, coworkers were very nice across the board
cons: The work itself was mostly just mindless data entry that didn't prepare me for employment after graduation. Looks ok on a resume, but it doesn't really qualify me for much. Didn't pay much either.

review_title: It was my favorite job at the time
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Lima, OH
pros: As a student employee, it was nice to be paid over minimum wage, and my supervisor was always willing to work around my school schedule.
cons: I received a work/study grant, which I though would go towards my tuition, but instead it was what the university used to pay me.  I still don't quite understand why the grant did not go toward my tuition, especially considering that I had the same job a semester before without a work/study grant, so it seems to me that the university was the only beneficiary of the grant.

review_title: My experience has been positive and rewarding.
pros: The Ohio State University is a friendly environment and it is good to be able to work with students in all years of college as well as older adults who guide these students.
cons: Working in the dining services can be difficult because sometimes there are unhappy customers, but as students there is only so much you can do to better the situation.

pros: Job security. There is high turnover due to PCAs becoming nurses, so there is is an ability to switch units and plenty of overtime opportunities. 401k with employer match, many paid holidays and you can earn 2 weeks of vacation a year that roll over up to 240 hours.
cons: very low pay. I started at 11.04 and now (6 years later) make $12.29. Even after getting an MBA, I have never been selected to even get an interview for entry-level managerial positions (not even housekeeping). You are better being a valet, who get more hourly pay than us and also get tips from unknowing patients.

review_title: A Collection of Narcissists - Run Away!
pros: There were pockets of good in this organization, but management never recognized or rewarded them. Most of the students were great, as were most of the Visiting Scholars, older Faculty & Staff.
cons:
Upper management was full of uber narcissists who never gave credit or praise, constantly pressured you for free O/T, and expected you to be perpetually on-call.  Employees are routinely degraded and treated as second-class citizens and whipping boys. Getting screamed at was a weekly function for my job, and was the norm for everyone, except their favorite few. 

Unless you're one of their favorites, you will have a hard time working there.

review_title: Very positive experience working here throughout my academic career.
pros:
The work hours were extremely flexible allowing you to schedule around your classes.
Very casual environment and pretty laid-back as long as your quota of things to do had been accomplished.
Able to study while working during night hours.
cons:
Some parts of the year (beginning, end) were more erratic and fast paced.
A lot of the work was done solo, so little opportunity to socialize.

review_title: Very positive experience, great people, great place to work.
pros:
The managers are very helpful and upbeat.
They treat you with respect and also joke around with you.
Fun work atmosphere when managers and others are in the office.
You are actually helping alumni and students while working.
cons: A lot of times you are in the office alone, so that can be boring at times. We are often mistaken as the front desk of the Union which can be confusing for people.

pros: The departments are very diverse. Numerous opportunities to participate in staff events and meet new people. The university treats it's staff well, and provides many benefits depending on the job. The university tends to be on the forefront of emerging technologies and practices.
cons: Parking can be a nightmare. My particular building requires a paid parking pass which can become expensive.

pros:
Fosters a very friendly and casual work environment.  Co-workers and those you serve can be very kind and accommodating... if nothing is wrong.  Work with these people long enough and they almost start to feel like family.

Also, your health care benefits are probably the best you'll ever find.
cons:
There are few opportunities for advancement and even less encouragement to better your skills.  A change in position is very often horizontal... at least for those of us in the lower ranks.  Also, any mistakes you make are rarely tolerated and overly emphasized compared to your contributions.  

The other 'benefits' you receive for working at OSU are superficial at best.  Sports ticket discounts are negligible.  You're actually better off selling your tickets to make money... that is if you're lucky enough to get any.  

And parking?  Don't get me started.  OSU may quote you a great salary when you're hired, but you know there are going to be taxes... that's just a given.  Any other job would give you a parking pass because after all, they need you (their employee) to operate.  OSU makes you pay hundreds of dollars to park, or perhaps thousands if you want to be anywhere close to your building.  Parking is a con job at the very best.

review_title: Decent part time job while attending school
job_title: Fawcett Center Server in Columbus, OH
pros: Low responsibility, given how replaceable you are, you can leave each shift knowing no one is relying on you specifically. Great for a college kid.
cons: The structure is getting better. The management, if you can call it that, used to be weak and expected students to take the job to a serious enough level to make up for their own slack. Getting better now.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Usually have some pretty positive people to work with -- a lot of diversity if you're looking for it and work can easily be meaningful if you find a research job that applies to your interests, whatever that may be. There are a few websites to help find jobs on campus and off-campus as well!
cons: Diversity of people -- not always a good thing. Some people are harder to work with than others naturally. Some communication problems tend to happen when there are so many people working part-time in any student position.

pros: Huge university with a lot of collaboration opportunities.
cons:
Lots of politics.
 
No Salary Standards what so ever. Most of the time, a fresh undergraduate degree holder earns more than what we earn here with a PhD degree.

If you are with the "RULING party, i.e., the chair etc.," you will be appointed as a Research Assistant professor with zero experience. But if you are on the wrong side, you may never get promoted beyond research scientist. 
 
You may see Chairs/professors with 6-7 years of experience with pathetic publications records.

pros: Nice Health insurance package for a family.  Cost of living is low but is increasing.  The campus is a nice place to walk around if you have time to do so.
cons: Bad pay as you would expect from a postdoc.  OPERS (Automatic 10% retirement taken out of your paycheck) really hurts your paycheck especially when this is a temporary position.

pros: Great benefits. 8:30-5 work day- everyone leaves right at 5. Ample opportunity to buy football tickets. Free education benefits for you, 50% off for your family. Job security- you have to really try to get fired.
cons: General apathy abounds- it's a government job. Anyone who is in the pension plan constantly talks how how long they until they can retire. Promotions are based on time in the job, not performance.

review_title: Great place to study and work, with lots of facilities and resources
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
1. One of the largest universities in US. With lots of facilities, resources, and good people.
2. School provides free shuttle bus around the campus.
3. Living expense is not so high in Columbus area
cons:
1. Public transportation system in the city is not well constructed; it only has bus running in few routes. For saving your time and being convenient, you would need a personal vehicle to get the place you want (e.g. grocery shopping). 
2. Winter is too cold (snowing) for people who like warm weather more.

pros: Coworkers have been great. If you plan on staying for a long time moving up is possible.  If you go to school at OSU while employed full-time they will pay for your school. They pay half of OSU tuition for kids of employees. This benefit is good, but unfortunately it factors into your benefits package and is part of OSU's justification for paying lower salaries even though most employees never use it.
cons:
Ohio State does anything and everything to extract money from people. As a student they charge you outrageous tuition and fees. Immediately after graduating they contact you to donate money to the school and as an alumni they never stop hounding you for donations.

As an employee, you are required to pay for parking. These are OSU lots, they are not competing with anyone else for these parking spots yet OSU puts its' cost onto the employees. OSU pays less than competitors and says it's because of the "great benefit package". The benefits are good surely, but do your homework, ask around to people you know at other big companies and you may find that OSU's benefits aren't actually that much better than other big companies. 

OSU boasts a 14% matching contribution to your retirement account. This can be a great benefit that can offset the lower salaries but be careful. You will default into one of the OPERs retirement plans and in these plans about 33% of that 14% is wiped out by mandatory fees. In the traditional pension plan you have to be at OSU for 5 years before you are 33% vested in your account and for 10 years to be 67% vested, but the remaining 33% is always wiped out for fees. The Alternate Retirement Plan is the best way to keep this great benefit they boast about. The 14% contribution becomes around 13% in this plan and you are completely vested after just 1 year. This way if you get fed up like me you can keep the money that they try very hard not to give you. 

There are two job classifications at OSU, CCS and A&P. CCS employees are essentially second class employees. They have outdated job titles straight from the 1950's. They have stricter policies that can lead to disciplinary action. They get less vacation time. They need to put in many more years of service at OSU than A&P people to get bumped up to more vacation time levels. 

Red tape abounds at OSU. Change is rare and anything that gets accomplished takes a very long time to do it. A key example of red tape is when I found myself not very busy with my job. I found a simple way I could help my team and take some of their work load. I presented it to my boss. Their response was that I couldn't because it wasn't in my job description. I had never encountered a situation where I asked a boss for more work and they said anything other than, "sure, thank you for the help."

pros:
The best reason to work for Ohio State are the benefits.  I was promoted from a student position, so Ohio State paid for me to complete my degree.  I'm currently thinking about a graduate level program which one of the reasons that I have stayed with the university.

The second big benefit of Ohio State is the benefits.  While health insurance has gotten worse and more expensive ever year it is available and is good enough.  They are also very supportive of taken time off for family; when my son was born I received a paternal leave of three weeks which did not count against accrued sick or vacation.  Exactly how accommodating the environment is largely depends on where you work; the academic side tends to demand more hours (typically closer to the 50+ hour work week) where the business units tend to favor closer to the 40 hour work week.
cons: The biggest downside is advancement and pay.  Since I started as a student every raise I have received has been capped at 10% and I received no raise in compensation for completing my degree.  My colleges who have left for other companies have all received very large raises (at least 20k+).  It seems the only way to really get a head of the university is to leave for awhile and then come back.  While that is nice to have people cycle in that have a different perspective, it doesn't seem fair that loyal employees are punished.

review_title: Hard work is rewarded equally to no work at all.
pros: The benefits are outstanding, especially if you plan on making a career at OSU.  It is very difficult to get fired.  Training and travel is often provided in addition to vacation, medical, dental, and vision.  There are staff development grants as well as free tuition.  There are a lot of nice people and you can learn at lot during your tenure.
cons: The politics are heartbreaking.  For an institution which prides itself on the mantra "Do Something Great", Ohio State in its actions encourages anything but that.  Hard work is rewarded equally to no work.  You can arrive late, spend your day socializing, take a two hour lunch, then leave early, and you will still get the same pay increase and performance review as the person who puts in nights, weekends, sweat, and tears.  Faculty run the University but they are often unaccounted for and unaccountable.  There are definitely some good areas to work, but they are the exception rather than the rule.  If you take pride in your work and expect your employer to do the same, you may reconsider working here.

review_title: Work was interesting and personally fulfilling
pros:
Work-life Balance was very great. It was possible to have a life outside of work.

Extremely Rewarding and Personally Fulfilling (non-financially).

Nearly all the employees I worked with were passionate about what they do for the community and students.

Amount of workload and expectations greatly depended on the nature and type of position.

My 'Middle' managers and lower, and those who worked directly with me and students were generally extremely passionate about what they do- most do the things they do for the students and not necessarily for personal, financial or professional gain. This alone created a great culture and provided a good work atmosphere.
cons:
Upper Management seemed to be completely out of touch with lower level employees' and students' real needs and sometimes even contradictory...

Nepotism and cronyism seemed to be rampant in my departments. This stifled personal and professional growth and advancement. The 3 year turnover rate of the full-time and non-student employees in the departments I worked for, were relatively high- greater than 50%. Sometimes, it was hard getting raises, promotions, or full-time employment unless you personally knew the 'powers that be' or were recommended for a position, raise, etc, from someone who knew 'the powers that be' regardless of performance.

Pay rate and benefits were on the low range for my positions except for high level management and tenure track professorships.

review_title: Good First Job for Building a Resume
pros:
No need for past dining service experience (or any job experience, for that matter), as long as you're friendly in the interview, they will probably hire you.
Emphasize cross training-- they encourage you to train in other areas of the Diner-- host, server, desert shop, cook, cashier, expo, dish. You really learn the ins and outs of a restaurant, which prepares you well if you want to work in dining in the future. 
The people there are really great to work with-- it definitely has a "work family" vibe. 
Very easy to move up-- promotions happen roughly once per semester. I think it depends on how much turnover they have in a given period of time, but when I worked there you could pretty easily become a Student Lead in just over a semester, and then a Student Manager within in a year if you are a good, dedicated worker. If you stick with them for years and continue to be a good worker you can even move up into higher management fairly easily.
When you work a closing shift (which, at the end of my time there, you were required to once per week) they raise your pay to $13/ hr for those shifts.
cons:
If you want to stick with one position, they might rope you into training in more areas of the restaurant (especially if you're a server or host), so that's something to consider if you don't want to learn a bunch of new positions. 
No tips-- but you get paid above minimum wage ($9/hr base pay). The upside to this is if you work on a Tuesday afternoon and only get 5 tables your whole shift, you don't have to worry about your paycheck suffering. But that also means if you work on a Saturday night and are running around like a mad person, or have an 11 top or something, you're getting paid the same amount as when you did basically nothing on that Tuesday afternoon.

review_title: Ohio State - look beyond sports and sentimentality if you want to work here.
pros: job security, sick time, football - if you are still into that after working here several years.
cons: Caste system.  It's probably good if you are a professor and great if you are in upper administration.

pros: Bosses were very flexible with work hours, you set your own.  You can call off if you need to for school. You can work more hours if needed.  Management was very supportive of me and my future career.
cons: The only con I can even think to come up with is that future employment opportunities were not existant.  It's a wonderful place to work.

pros: Good benefits both health and additional benefits, free tuition for employees, severance package for low-level employees, easy to get a job if you know someone
cons: Low pay, bad attitude towards staff, excessive "politics", toxic environment (dependent on department/unit), excessive time taken for the slightest decisions, definitely got a sexist/female-supremecy vibe from many female co-workers and superiors, constantly felt unappreciated.

review_title: Excellent, interesting, and supportive environment for staff.
pros: It's a great relaxed environment, but not so relaxed that it is boring or non-challenging.  Co-workers and other staff members are supportive and friendly and most of the time it just feels like a large family.  There seems to always be someone around with just the experience you need to solve a new problem.  Things seem to be getting more organized all the time.
cons: Pay feels a little under the industry standard.  Career advancement opportunities seem limited. More organization also seem to mean more bureaucracy.

job_title: Laboratory Animal Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Good work environment.  Salary is good.  Management is kind to employees and promotes respect among the team.  There are lots of potlucks and good communication among employees.  No overtime required but plenty offered.
cons: Little room for growth or advancement.  There are a lot of politics.  It depends on who you know that determines if you can move to a better position.

review_title: A fulfilling and fun place to work
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Leadership is very cognizant and appreciative of staff. There are many opportunities for employees to contribute and lead positive efforts.
