There is a strong culture of teamwork toward a shared mission.  Students are integrated into nearly every aspect of university operations and adminstration.  This keeps the institution on focus and provides an invigorating atmosphere for workers of all ages.
cons: As a city of 100,000 people, parking is naturally less than ideal for the individual each day.  But as a community, it is rather efficient.

pros: Medical benefits, location, and if you like sports this is your place.
cons: Sports dominated university, across the board the arts are not well funded and supported. This is primarily a research university (medical, sciences).

review_title: Very Unorganized and Unstable.  Stay Away.
pros: The benefits and people are great! You really have the opportunity to make a difference in someones live.
cons: The pay is not comparable to the area. Management is young and inexperienced. They do not manage finances well leading to unneeded employee lay-offs. Management also doesn't care about the staff and would rather you not inconvenience them with legitimate problems. If you are looking for a stable, respectable option, go somewhere else.

review_title: This is the job I took when I desperately needed a job
pros:
The people there are mostly kind and do not make you work until you die.
Personally, the painting part was kinda relaxing.
cons:
You learn to paint poorly
They make you sit and watch paint dry but you can't study because you'll get paint on everything
You will work with people who do not care to paint or paint correctly. 
You will need a set of paint clothes and pants. I got paint on a pair of shorts and pants. 
Be prepared for people to judge you based on that.

review_title: Made Great Connection but Supervisor is TERRIBLE!!
pros: Flexible schedule, great experience with the university, if a full-time employee you can get a discount on taking courses at the university.
cons: Most of the work is working alone, the office was structured around having little interaction with co-workers, the office can be toxic at times with people "telling on" one another to the boss.

pros: The job was very flexible. My manager was always willing to work around school and other activities. It was also a very social job. I got to know the people in my dorm really well. If I had free time during my shifts, I was allowed to do homework.
cons: There wasn't too much to complain about. The only really negative aspect of the job was that the hours sucked. Sometimes I would have to work straight through the middle of the night and then only have eight hours until my next shift.

review_title: Ohio State is incredibly flexible and reasonable with school requirements.
job_title: Windows Consultant and Commuter Liaison in Columbus, OH
pros: While attending Ohio State, there could not be a better job than to work there as well. It's convenient, flexible, and the management in the offices I worked in were incredibly reasonable when it came to school assignments.
cons: In all honesty, I cannot think of any cons. Some friends who have worked in the dining facilities have had bad experiences, but I have not with my TA and office work.

review_title: Good place to work for students
job_title: Help Desk Operator in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Convenient if you go to school here
- Flexible hours with class/exams taking priority
- Good variety in types of jobs and workload.
cons:
- Student jobs are close to minimum wage and the raises (if any) are small, regardless of amount of work done. Some jobs are much better than others in this respect, though.
- Ideas for positive changes are rarely, if ever, considered.
- Avoid working for dining services.

review_title: Good place to work if you know what you're getting into
pros: I was given exceptional opportunities to work from home and maintain a non-traditional work schedule.
cons: Advancement opportunities and career development was minimal. Promotions often seemed to reward social/networking skills. The culture is very insulated and politicized. Cronyism abounds and is one of the greatest obstacles to advancement. Management often lacks experience leading people and as a result, many of my problems are due to managers with poor people/management skills.

job_title: Patient Phone Service Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: Good benefits. Flexibility with schedule.
cons: Low pay.No room for advancement in scheduling. The benefits become more expensive over the years. OPERS takes a significant amount of your pay, which is fine if you're just beginning your career.  Non state positions are better for a person in their mid 40's or older if you've already been under an employer who deducts social security.  People with a college are treated with more respect and have room for advancement.

pros: The benefits are great!  Also, you often have control of your schedule and much autonomy.  The university has tons of relationships with vendors so you are always getting great discounts!  Oh you get FREE tuition...
cons: The benefits are great but the Salaries suck!  Also, politics are the rule of the day so be prepared to play them

job_title: Events Manager/Program Supervisor in Columbus, OH
pros: Meeting great artists, people from all walks of life, seeing great art, plays, music as well as world class lectures, great films, etc.  Good entry level position into C-bus community!
cons: As a tempory part time position, it is tough to get by on limited hours per week.....but it is a wonderful position to get started in the OSU community & move on from there.  Perfect place to begin if you are new to C-bus & want to connect with great peeps & professionals!

pros: The university has a good retirement through Public Employees Retirement System.  Good benefits.
cons: If you have been employed for a good lenght of time with the university, it may affect your ability to change positions within the university without taking a paycut.

pros:
- You choose your hours
- There is a standardized system for wages
- You will work with great individuals
- You will obtain useful experiences
cons: The only con I can think of is that you are paid minimum wage with pretty measly raises. However, as a student, there is really no need to ask for more with a job like this.

pros: Awesome experience - such a great clientele. I loved looking at all the books and reading some of them. That was important to me during the slow times.
cons: Working with others was really easy but sometimes it wasn't. Some of the students would make noise and I would tell them to be quiet with a please. I didn't mind it too much.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student
pros:
The University has excellent resources, including fantastic online journals and libraries
The environment can be very collegial among students and between faculty and students, though this seems to vary a lot across the University
Good quality of life on a  student stipend
cons:
Winters can be harsh
Some buildings are pretty badly in need of repair, though this seems to be more the exception than the rule

pros:
A very cool, active work environment (RPAC) 
Lots of coworkers/peers that make it a fun place to work
cons:
Former manager was very unforgiving with their schedule
software system used is god awful and crashes ALL the time, leaving member services employees to fend for themselves constantly in front of dissatisfied customers

review_title: An inspiring place for research about finance
pros: Faculty are supportive. The program is designed to help PhD students, so students feel like colleagues, not 'students'. Leading faculty are thoughtful about the design of the PhD program and other professors demand reasonable amount of work on students while considering how best the work can help the students grow.
cons: Not sure, but I would love to have more opportunities to be connected to outside faculty based on OSU faculty's connection through joint research projects. This will increase the students' exposure to learning more.

review_title: Good benefits and work environment, but stress is going nowhere but up.
pros:
- Salary has been reasonable and is generally open to negotiation
- Excellent working environment, agreeable coworkers
- Doing generally interesting and varied research work
cons: The OSU administration has recently been expecting more out of its full-time staff, including undergraduate mentorships, additional publications, and a higher class load -- without increasing pay.

pros: They were very warm and welcoming. Even at first when I was asking a lot of questions...they were kind. The benefits are great and I'd love to TEMP there again. It's a great place to work with so many talented people.
cons: I did not like the commute. There were a lot of people to get to know there. Was sad temp assignment ended.

review_title: Best Place I've Eve Ever Worked
job_title: Senior Program Manager (Non Academic Area) in Columbus, OH
pros: Generous sick and vacation leave time plan, employee-centered wellness incentive plan, encourages professional and career development no matter what your position, partial tuition reimbursement for self and dependents.
cons: Large state bureaucracy sometimes slows things down, pay scale is slowly catching up to private sector but benefits are generally better than private, lots of rules but for good reason, very hard to get an interview if from outside

review_title: Ohio State- A Good Place To Work
job_title: Research Lab Tech in Columbus, OH
pros: Prestigious university, interaction with diverse ethnic community, excellent job benefits, ample opportunity for advancement, paid holidays and ample sick and personal leave time.
cons: Some levels of management seem unsympathetic to problems encountered by workers; ongoing problems with parking; educational opportunities for workers somewhat rigid.

pros: Convenient, flexible hours, very supportive, well-trained and fantastic, friendly supervisors that care about us and our success as employees, students and people. Good training, enjoyable work environment, free housing for the school year.
cons: Only allowed to work for the university for 28 hours a week, even via different jobs. As such a major employer in the area, that makes it hard to get multiple jobs because you have to go quite a way to get a non-OSU job for extra hours sometimes. Low pay (stipend).

review_title: Highs and lows, but overall a positive experience
pros: I worked for some wonderful supervisors and on a great team; I learned a lot. there was an overall positive environment.
cons: Senior management changed a lot and not in a good way - there is no strategy or passion in the newest hires and it reflected poorly on the overall office culture. Every unit I worked in had the worst HR people - condescending, don't advocate for employees, simply follow what they're told by higher ups

pros: Flexible working opportunity, provides a good number of hours for employees, great environment to develop a relationship with staff members and with residents.
cons: Expects resident advisors to work constantly for random parts of the university, not flexible with training... even if a returning res life member.

job_title: Research Lab Technician in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Great fellow employees to work with and learn from. 
- A constant learning environment that can open up a lot of doors for career paths. 
- Flexible hours
cons:
- the pay could be higher, but it is a university job
- grant searching can be a difficult task. 
- tasks can feel redundant at times.

pros:
It's always a great day to be a Buckeye!
Some of the most approachable, friendly, and supportive leadership is here at this University.
Access to many resources throughout the University and Columbus, Ohio.
Columbus, Ohio is an increasingly pleasant place to live.
cons:
Depending on your department, it could be easy to feel like a number. Immerse yourself in networking across multiple departments to build a strong and valuable network.
Has a lot of the red tape attributed to large organizations, and can get very annoying in this way.

review_title: Great benefits, frustrating management at times
pros: OSU has an excellent benefits package. More sick leave than most people will ever use, vacation time separate from sick leave, great insurance, free tuition if you want to take classes.
cons: Upper management often changes policies on its own accord without consulting with the people doing the work. This seems to be a university-wide phenomenon and not a unique problem for any particular college or department.

pros: The life working on campus is invigorating.  You feel a part of something bigger than yourself.  You have plenty of opportunities to get involved in a huge variety of organizations or activities.
cons: The are times when the bureaucracy of working for the government gets old.  Seeing how money is wasted can make you lose satisfaction in what you are going.

pros: It's easy work, the hours are relatively flexible, nice people for the most part, and opportunities to get a raise.
cons: It's only easy to get hired if you're a student, otherwise good luck. Most managers are good, but it's kind of hit or miss.

pros: Great benefits, which are second to none in my experience, health, education, miscellaneous discounts, great job security (sometimes to a fault = freeloaders).
cons: Lots of bureaucracy. It takes forever to get anything done and meetings about setting meetings, to then ask permission to create change are commonplace. Very often these meetings stall before any action occurs. Also, the good job security creates freeloading.

job_title: Disability Program Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU is a very diverse organization and offers many different positions to support both the university and medical center.  Great benefits and wellness incentives.
cons: OSU is a huge organization and one can feel lost, overwhelmed in the bureaucracy. The workload of my position in was too varied which made the number of responsibilities and duties very difficult to complete in a timely manner given all the meetings we had to attend. There are actually meetings about meetings.

pros: Campus is an exciting place to work.  There is always something going on and always some free promotional stuff being given away.  There is a friendly atmosphere and you feel like you are a positive addition to the university.  The benefits are great.  Especially since you can take classes and participate in the activities going on around campus.
cons: Driving around on game days.  Dealing with stressed out students during exam periods.

review_title: Civil, Environmental, and Geodetic Engineering Graduate Research Associate
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
Faculty advisers seem to care and are good to work with
Opportunity for funded position
Lots of resources available to assist with projects
cons:
Bureaucracy prioritized over learning; administrators have larger and better offices than tenured professors
Shifting away from quality education practices
Graduate students relegated to small and unimproved spaces
Hours reported will not correspond to hours worked
Poor pay
Large employee turnover means that administrative functions are disorganized

review_title: Very political climate when it comes to tenure.
pros: Junior faculty receive some support from colleagues
cons: Lots of politics. People with smile to your face and stab you in the back. Trust no one. Absolutely no mentorship is provided whatsoever.

pros: Broad community of talented contributors, strong support for necessary security and training.
cons: Direct compensation not as competitive, opportunities for promotion are few and far between without changing business units

pros: Work is super easy. Everyone is really laid back and it is really easy to study and do other things even while you are at work. Very low turnover.
cons: Pay isn't that great, but for a part time student job what can you expect. Raises are also few and far between.

review_title: The Ohio State Buckeyes, whether students or employees, they are very diverse, friendly, well educated and experienced.
pros: The Ohio State University is a Research based university whereby students have multiple opportunities to interact and work with professors on many different researches in all types of fields
cons: The Ohio State University is  a huge campus filled with many students that compete with you, so you must be sure to stay on top if you are to be the best, otherwise you will always find opportunities here.

review_title: A bit like a big family...or cult...depending on your perspective :)
pros: This will vary greatly with what school/org you're in - ours was very casual work environment, flexible work schedule, working from home sometimes, generous health benefits/sick and vacation time, tuition.
cons: Poor management structure and oversight, very high salaries for some, very low for others. No room/place for advancement. Very little training offered or encouraged. Workloads are abysmally low at times.

pros:
Great Workplace environment and friendly coworkers.
The boss is very optimistic and down to earth.
The work is monotonous but not to difficult.
cons:
Pay is not high. 
Little to no growth in student position, I believe you get a 25 cent raise every semester.
Real world applicability is limited to theater and library sciences.

pros: The work environment was always incredible. The staff at my current job is the best staff I have ever interacted with and I was lucky to receive the opportunity that they gave me.
cons: I do not really have any cons about the job, I am a working through a work/study and I have never had any complaints.

pros: flexible scheduling options,  excellent training,  excellent colleagues, great students, office hours at your convenience, good office space,  free printing and copying under a certain page limit
cons: Some upper levels are very bureaucratic and unhelpful, health insurance plan isn't that great, you kind of jump right in in the beginning with little guidance and it can be a bit intimidating

review_title: Went to OSU, worked in research and etc.
pros: Lots of opportunities to go, but frankly I was not able to take advantage of the things
cons: Bullied nonstop by graduate students while trying to do research. A lot of childish behavior. I might have gotten unlucky and thrown into a bad lab, as others didn't seem to have problems. However the professor of the lab and the associated graduate students at the time were reckless, careless and didn't really seem to want to be there. Kind of a joke.

review_title: Try to find a better alternative
pros:
- Readily assign independent instruction which is a great resume builder
- Good student evaluations are rewarded
- Pay starts very low, but then raised a bit every year until a level higher than average other departments.
cons:
- Geared more toward teaching and less research
- Offices stink!!!
- Management is not interested in hearing from employees at all

review_title: Great part time job during schooling
pros: Working at the front desk offers great connections with management and residents. Residence halls provide a fun work atmosphere. Employees choose their own schedule and work with other current students.
cons: Employees are constantly competing for extra hours, making it tough to make a significant amount of money. Most extra hours usually come from overnight shifts.

review_title: Worked there for years as a student
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: They are very understanding with a student's work schedule - if you have something pop up and you have to go study, they always understood. Provided me with great & flexible hours: during school I could work around 20 a week but during breaks they easily let me go up to 40.
cons: The pay was decent, nothing compared to what you could make serving at a nice restaurant or paid internships. No benefits, but I was a student.

pros: It is convenient if you are a student at Ohio State. A job on campus allows for less back and forth travel time.
cons: Ohio State claims to be in a hiring freeze at the moment so the process of getting a job that is not meant for student's with work study can be very long and extraneous.

pros: It was a wonderful experience. Flexible work schedule with easy training, and the student manager was friendly. Furthermore, it was easy to go to work.
cons: The job could seem boring at time due to its simplistic nature. Also, rotation sometime can come in too quickly. The work station probably take a little more time to get used to.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: This position offers great exposure to the academic side of research and is a great starting point for students considering a career in research or looking to go to medical school. Oftentimes experience is not expected or required and they will teach you a lot if you are willing to learn.
cons: This job does not pay as well as some other college jobs, especially for all that you may be doing. My hourly wage started at $8.10/hr and was raised once to $8.26/hr.

review_title: If you need the money, go for it.
job_title: Student Athlete Tutor in Columbus, OH
pros: My supervisors were very understanding and nonjudgmental when I made mistakes. I really appreciated that.
cons: Most of the athletes I tutored were taking blow-off classes that they didn't care about. Future tutors should aim for upper-level classes; the students there care more. Also, the strict NAACP rules made me feel like part of a caste system.

pros: Friendly work environment was a huge plus. Flexible scheduling and willingness to work around a busy students schedule. Ideal job for any student. Being able to study while working is another plus!
cons: Someone had to be working 24/7 so this means occasionally getting stuck with late night and super early morning shifts. You cant apply for this job if you live off campus. Not much to complain about great opportunity for students on campus.

review_title: Takes a while to get used to, but there are pros.
pros: Wide range of research being conducted in a large, diverse department. If you make the effort to find them there are some lovely areas, and people in Columbus!
cons: It is a very large university, which makes it easy to get lost in the crowd, however, there are numerous helpful resources available to staff when you can find them.

pros: Great flexibility in work time per standard university life.  Cutting edge research with contacts through different projects.
cons: Low pay compared to an industry position.  Not a great stepping stone towards industry in general if that's what you want.

review_title: Was told that my opinion mattered, but found out that is not true.
job_title: RN Case Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Great benefits, I felt that I was professionally honored for my role. Was proud to be working with such great physicians And Students, residence and nurses.
cons: Very large campus to cover entire campus within my department.

review_title: What its like to work at The OSU School Newspaper The Lantern as an ad sales rep
pros: great hours and work on commission with 11% of all sales.
cons: hard to get new account. Seniority and luck are the way to go. Until you inherit some big account you wont be making any money.

pros: Great benefits.  Great environment.  Job stability.  Building a network of people is easy.  A lot of opportunity to be involved with community programs.
cons: Little opportunity for career advancement.  Limited pay scale.  Lack of communication between departments that have to work together.

review_title: Overall a good place to work for slow pace person
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Really good health insurance, nice work environment, good work/life balance, nice people to work with, beautiful campus, well developed sports culture, some research programs are very competitive.
cons: Low salary, slow pace, not much career opportunities, management is quite political as an university, constantly spending money on building construction.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Worked with the College of Engineering in the Civil Engineering department, the hours worked around my class schedule and my professor/mentor was an incredible person.
cons: Wouldn't rollover my employee status into the summer, and told me at the last minute. Couldn't work any more hours that 28 per week during the school year.

review_title: Education  growth but no career development
pros: Tuition waiver is awesome. Coworkers are very friendly and fun to work with.
cons: Will always be second class compared to faculty. They push you to get their masters degrees and PhD to make it seem like everyone needs one to advance. Higher ed is just a big  pyramid scheme

pros: The Office Assistant position allowed for great flexibility in your student schedule, allowing you to work when you want and for the number of hours you would like (usually). You could do homework or watch Netflix at the desk as long as your other tasks were completed.
cons: The 24/7 desk aspect caused you to get some shifts you would be less than excited for. Management could be a bit strict sometimes for a job that isn't too serious.

review_title: I can improve my ability greatly here by completing my graduate degree.
pros: It's a world-famouse university and has a lot of resources here. As a MS student in ECE department, I have a lot of knowledge to learn.
cons: The competition in ECE department is very intensive, and the quarter system is a little bit too short for stepping into some field.

review_title: I learned a lot & got some really good experience but it came at the price of my sanity since there's so much politics.
pros:
Hard to get fired if actually hired.
Medical benefits were really good.
Free education to work towards a degree.
cons:
Extremely political environment with everyone having an agenda
Terrible dental and vision benefits.
Mounds of pointless paperwork for every single transaction.

review_title: some aspects are great, some need help.
pros: Health benefits. retirement system. often a sense of pride to work here. the pay (sometimes). college atmosphere. co-workers. working with students and to see them develop and mature.
cons: parking - both cost and availability. If you work as Civil Service, it can be dificult to move up. so much focus on student development, the staff are often left behind. college atmosphere.

pros: Good insurance coverage, opportunities to learn new technologies and deal with a large number of buildings and environments. Some great coworkers.
cons: Lack of career development and career path. Little / no room for raises or promotions. Great deal of complacency among long time employees. No opportunities to work from home and limited / no flex time.

pros: Learn communication skills and review the java algorithm again. Build network with professors and instructor and good students. Get refer from the professors.
cons: Low salary. Repeat grading same material each semester kind of boring. Cannot grade exam, only grade homework and lab assignment. Few people come to office to ask your question.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Decent pay for a physics graduate student. Large number of professors working in a diversity of physics subfields. Excellent facilities for theory and experiment.
cons: I haven't found much to complain about. If I had to say something, it would be that the colloquium coffee is really bad.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Excellent administrative help and preparation for first time time teachers. Most professors are great to work with, however there can always be exceptions.
cons: Which professors you work under is somewhat based on luck. College students are a mixed bag, some are caring and enthusiastic, while others could care less.

pros: Great place to work, job security a stable brand and positive work environment- somewhat flexible hours, good benefits too
cons: The pay is lowery than private industry jobs, not as flexible on schedules as agencies and private industry advancement opportunities can be slow or non existent

review_title: solid work experience. low pay but great benefits
job_title: Office Administrative Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU has great benefits! OSU pays much less than industry but makes up for it with their benefits, including tuition waivers and health incentives
cons: Low pay... OSU pays much less than industry but makes up for it with their benefits.  If it weren't for their benefits, I think they'd lose alot of really qualified people.

review_title: As expected, OSU is one giant bureaucracy.
pros:
-Work/life balance (flexible schedules, work from home, etc.)
-Excellent benefits (health care, adoption assistance, discount programs, free tuition, child care, etc.)
cons:
-Top down management
-People "on the ground" aren't valued
-Lack of mobility career-wise
-Parking (lack of and cost)

review_title: Good place for part time work
pros: I worked at Oxleys by the numbers and they were very flexible with the hours I worked. The campus dining services is a great place to work part time while taking classes
cons: Pay is just average but was what was expected for part time work in a kitchen. I have no other complaints

pros: They were flexible with my schedule because I was a full time student.  I worked on research that was going into a science article.  The professor I work with was very knowledgeable.
cons: There were times when I couldn't work for a quarter because there was not enough assignments or too many students working for the professor.

review_title: High Quality of work, Excellent infrastructure and knowledgeable superiors.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: The Professors here(in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, where I work) are very helpful and knowledgeable in their area of research. The university attracts funding from many federal agencies and therefore infrastructure/research equipment is never an issue. Apart from academics, campus life is very vibrant and is huge... lot of opportunities for physical activity/creative pursuits.
cons: Graduate Research Assistants do not get paid very much, compared to the work they put in.

review_title: Ohio State University provides many opportunities to learn from world class researchers.
pros: OSU offers great health insurance, incredible resources for doing all types of research, and many diverse researchers to network and collaborate with.
cons: As a large institution, there are some challenges to obtaining personal guidance and addressing difficult situations in a timely manner.

pros: The hours they let you work are VERY flexible because they understand you are a student first and foremost. Every supervisor is also very friendly and the workloads are very manageable.
cons: Pay is 8.10 (minimum wage) roughly everywhere across The Ohio State University except for a jew jobs like bus drivers. I know the school is sitting on top of billions of dollars they could use to pay their workers a little bit more but oh well.

review_title: Not horrible but not super fantastic either
pros: Medical Benefits are great. The pay rate for my job role is good.
cons: Parking is outrageously expensive. My Department doesn't have a budget to do fun things. There's a lot of cliques and nepotism. It gets irritating walking everywhere, especially in bad weather. There is no decently priced food around the area.  A lot of the buildings are old and crappy.

review_title: Dont work in IT at OSU
pros: Good benefits from the university.  Smart and friendly people.  Campus is beautiful.
cons: IT departments are all messed up.  There are 30 IT departments, almost one for each college, each with their own budget.   OSU is also impacted by Federal and State funding shortfalls.  Be careful if you want to work there.  They have a lot of layoffs.

pros: The campus is great, with lots of facilities. The benefits were adequate, with dental and vision plans included in the health insurance package.
cons: It's a huge university, so sometimes there may be lack of or delayed communication among departments. I had no spouse or children, so I cannot say about health coverage for relatives.

job_title: Assistant Research Engineer in Columbus, OH
pros: Friendly and helpful people abound at Ohio State.  People are positive and genuinely want to help you and hear what you are doing.  The environment is stimulating and the benefits package is good too!
cons: Sometimes, decisions at the university seem to be guided by money more than by what is the best for it's students and staff.  Expect to jump through hoops when trying to get things approved within the university.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Great health insurance, many free programs, great 401K match if staying at least 5 years, good student stipend, free financial advisors, free counseling services, free nutritionist advise, free bus access, free gym memberships. Work/life balance is encouraged in grad school, but not always attainable depending on who you work with.
cons: Really big community (only a con if you don't like a big campus). Not very diverse.

pros: Some autonomy and a great student body
cons: The campus faculty culture is dominated by the good ol boys and girls club who are self aggrandizing low quality and non innovative professionals - this place needs young and progressive leadership by people that were not indoctrinated by the ancients

pros: It's nice because you get to work alongside other students and the job isn't too difficult.  It does get tedious, but the work environment itself is really positive.
cons: As I mentioned before, the workload is pretty tedious.  That is probably the only real con about working at Undergraduate Admissions.

review_title: It is great experience to work at OSU.
pros:
1/ It is one of the largest single campus in the States.
2/ A lot of interdisciplinary research is going go.
cons:
1/ Some  of the departments is huge and it is bureaucratization.
2/ Need more effort to promote innovation and creativity.

pros: Research universities offer faculty great freedom and support, especially if you want to be entrepreneurial with your scholarship. Ohio State is a good one. Senior management is mainly run by academics.
cons: Has the cons of a large organization. Bureaucracy never decreases.  Finance and  low-level admin are poorly done, by people who might not hold down a job in a more competitive environment

review_title: Successfully developed soft skills for use in the future
pros: Amazing location and opportunities are plentiful. Plenty of opportunities for student involvement and participation in leadership.
cons: Undergraduate students working for the University are deemed to not have any valuable input for leadership. It is very difficult to get support for new ideas without the backing of many higher-ups.

pros: Large university with lots to do and good facilities, excellent libraries and IT.
cons: The workload for full-time foreign language teaching is ridiculous (16 credit hours) and the pay is the lowest for same position/rank among R1 universities. For comparison: Other Midwestern universities of similar rank pay 35-39K for a 12-credit load for the same subject. OSU pays 32K for 16 credits. Lecturers are not considered faculty, so they are also ineligible for most competitive funding on campus.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
I am a graduate research and teaching associate in CSE department.
1. relaxing environment, not that competitive, moderate academic pace, flexible time  
2. beautiful campus. convenient transportation and facility 
3. people are friendly and willing to help most of the time
cons:
1. Less competitive and well known than many famous universities
2. Low pay, no benefits or bonus 
3. lack opportunities to intern in industry

review_title: Like the position, but working for the university is a pain
pros: None about the university. The 20 word minimum requirement does not help because there is nothing positive to say that has not already been said.
cons: University bureaucracy, can never get things accomplished. That is really that most annoying aspect of working with any public university. If you like to get things done and not be micromanaged, avoid academia. Only full professors have that kind of luxury.

job_title: Systems Development Engineer in Columbus, OH
pros: Great sports teams and growing educational prestige. Free tuition for me and half price tuition for family. Good and affordable benefits.
cons: Class system among and between various levels of faculty and staff. Pay is low and can be as much as 50% of comparable Central Ohio jobs despite the growing 24/7 work requirements. Parking is expensive given the difficulty of finding available parking spaces.

review_title: OSU is a high quality university with a clear vision for transforming the Land Grant mission for the 21st Century.
pros: The pros of working for OSU are that the institution provides satisfactory compensation, good students, visionary leadership, great benefits, and stimulating colleagues. Overall there are great things going on at OSU.
cons: Trends in competitive funding of the public sector research has made the job of being a professor less enjoyable than when I started in 2000.

pros: University employment ensures flexible hours and great opportunities. Students have great opportunity to gain valuable real world experience, and great references to use in their post-grad job endeavors.
cons: Large university often leads to issues falling through the cracks. Organization and other practices can often be messy and not there, depending on the operation.

pros:
Benefits (Vacation, Health, Retirement)
Half Decent work life for low level positions.
cons: Low Compensation, Employee Appreciation, Modernization, Disorganization

review_title: Good opportunity to fund your studies
pros:
All is dependent on your specific unit, but I have:
- Flexible hours
- Holidays off (national holidays and from Dec 15 until the start of spring semester)
- Solid healthcare
- Most tuition and fees covered
- you can get public retirement
cons:
- ok stipend
- all the pros are not uniform across Ohio State units, except for healthcare and tuition coverage.
- if you are not strict, you could end up doing more than 20hrs

pros: Good people, good working environment, resources available in plenty, heart of the city, excellent pay, eligible to take courses from OSU
cons: Not much of cons to working at the ohio state university.  One would be, there is constant construction projects going around campus throughout the year. Public Movement is hindered

review_title: Good support for TAs in CLSE
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistantship in Columbus, OH
pros: Decent stipend as a TA, supportive staff, many opportunities to improve teaching ability through the workshops offered. Everyone at CLSE is very devoted to making sure students and TAs have the best possible experience at Ohio State.
cons: Health insurance costs are fairly high, limited spots for contractors after graduation, little room for advancement, though most people are just taking the job for experience or until they get a career elsewhere.

pros: It is easy to do you duties here and there isn't the pressure of sell,sell, sell. It's kinda like a walled off garden that once you get in you never want to leave.
cons: The pay is not a competitive as other places but the benefits are good. They won't hire you if you don't have a degree. They only respect their own.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: I was a graduate student in the physics department and was very impressed with the department administration.  They were always very helpful and genuinely care about the students' success.
cons: The hours as a graduate student doing research are long and hard, but I think this is typical of any school.

job_title: Research and Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: We don't need to pay tuition that is a huge money for an international students. Besides, our spouse can also have a good health insurance.
cons: The contract said that every week working time is about 20 hours but it really depends on your advisor. Sometimes it is much more than 20 hours.

pros: The hours were great. The people and employees at ohio state were very friendly and helpful. I can see myself working there again in the future.
cons: Pay was not enough; for the research we were doing, the compensation was not sufficient. The housing was not good either.

review_title: Temporary position, great work with students
pros: Enjoyed interaction with students, subject matter, and developing students into critical thinkers when it comes to education.  Developed professional relationships with students that extended into mentor experiences in the future.
cons: As a temporary lecturer, there isn't the opportunity to create relationships with other faculty.  Can be isolating to only be in the building once a week.  Little guidance from department heads since your not full time faculty.

pros: OSU is an excellent university for collaborative research in Chemical Engineering. A lot of great analytical facilities are available all through campus. A dedicated team of professors, researchers and staff scientists work together to solve problems in nanotechnology, catalysis and energy.
cons: As a graduate research assistant, finding the right work/life balance is always tricky. Plus, teaching assistantship is mandatory. While fulfilling in its own right, this does take time away from research.

job_title: Laboratory Animal Technologist in Wooster, OH
pros: Medical, Vision, Dental, Retirement, Independent work environment, tuition assistance (employee, dependents), professional development, leadership opportunities, paid vacation, comp time, paid military leave, medical leave, over time
cons: pay is low in research positions across campus, over an hour to main campus (Columbus), mandatory over time, some positions offer little to no growth unless you transfer departments/positions

review_title: Great school with great education included
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: earn an education while working nearly full time for a fraction of the price, good benefits, revamping HR to make it more streamlined and intuitive, state benefits
cons: Issues with recent news and lawsuits that may leave you questioning the integrity of the university. Ohio State needs a major revamp of demonstrating better ethics and morals

review_title: Good place to learn and grow
pros: They have world class researchers with enough funding to enable you to pursue a variety of projects. There are also some excellent interdisciplinary programs.
cons: compared to other Big 10 schools the salary is a bit lower  and they don't cover as much of the benefit costs.

review_title: Excellent benefits but no clear path for advancement
pros: Benefits are amazing.  Medical plans are better than anywhere else I've worked, and you can take classes for free.  Flexible schedule and work-life balance. Intellectual atmosphere and lots of engagement.
cons: No clear career path for staff.  Parking is outrageous.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: A lot of leading and productive research. A lot of graduate programs support full tuition + stipend through graduate assistantships.
cons: On the flip side of leading and productive research, researchers often come off cold. This may be needed to produce great work, but the environment is not for everyone.

review_title: Only worked for a summer, but good experience
pros: The research group that I worked with had rigorous but realistic expectations, provided adequate training for my experience level, and was generally very supportive. I didn't really deal much with general employee services, mostly just my research group, but my experiences were positive.
cons: I didn't really experience any cons working here, though I was only an undergraduate at the time looking for a summer research job.

pros: Good work enviornmnet.  Friendly managment.  Good at working around class chedule.  Pay was decent.  flexible hours that can be set by you.
cons: scheduling was difficult.  requests off where sent to manages and not relayed back to you in a timely manner. a

review_title: Good pay, good benefits, but no raises and alot of people who dont work very hard because of job security.
pros: Great benefits, free schooling, good time off, flexible work environment
cons: not the best employees because everyone has job security.  annoying to see how state money is really spent

pros:
Many different career paths.
Good benefits.
Students are wonderful and make you feel young again.
Columbus is a very liveable place.
cons:
Pay is OK, not great.
Conservative thinking.
Slow to make changes.
State support is on a steady decline.
Management is sometimes opaque.

pros: Flexible working hours and schedule. Low stress, and easygoing. If you like college sports then you're sure to like the buckeyes winning streak in football and basketball.
cons: Parking is terrible, parking cost are to expensive and not enough parking spaces, staff spend 15 minutes a day searching for parking. Staff salaries are 10 years behind the times. Health care costs rises every year and cover less options. Tuition benefits continue to be reduced.

pros: pay is low, but the work is now tough. The most important thing is follow a nice professor. And after 5-6 years you can get a phd degree
cons: it takes to long to get the degree, and sometimes your research work is not related to what you are interest in ..

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Columbus, OH
pros: Better opportunity in moving forward in receiving additional Education and Degrees.
cons: Creating the right team. and coaching and managing people.

pros: Flexible schedule, ability to connect with current students and positively mold their Ohio State experience, free housing and a biweekly stipend
cons: Sometimes the part-time position feels like a full-time position; sometimes syncing outside commitments with the job is more difficult

review_title: Excellent pay and benefits for Patient Care Associates
job_title: Patient Care Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Excellent on the job training
- Most nursing staff was friendly and helpful to new PCA's
-  Pay was excellent (started at $10.00/hr. in 2001 and advanced to over $14/hr. in less than a couple of years working midnight shift)
- Excellent cooperation between PCA's and RN's
cons: - No certification given for all of the skills learned means no ability to transfer them to another facility

pros: Excellent benefits (medical, vision, dental, HSA, FSA, retirement pensions, etc). Positive work environment. I enjoy being a part of such a large community of educators, researchers, and students striving to make positive impacts on the world.
cons: Starting pay for a research assistant with a bachelors is very low. They do not give any plans or timelines for raises. Parking can be very difficult / expensive at such a large university.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: The university is know for its Innovative Research in so many fields. this helps students learn and be able to contribute when they get out there. Also, the university gas great intellectuals from whom the students learn from,
cons: The university is pretty large and it's so easy to feel small and insignificant. some fields are very competitive with limited resources that cannot be distributed to everyone.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
Decent pay considering the low living expense in Columbus OH.
Not too much work load.
Learn a lot in the lab.
cons:
Working environment is poor. Even no window in my office.
Parking is horrible, even for someone with a staff parking permit.

review_title: One of the best places to do electromagnetics, antennas, RF research
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: ElectroScience Laboratory has a flexible environment, where there are many opportunities to get involved in ground-breaking research. The professors are very knowledgeable and willing to assist in any ways possible.
cons: There is a tendency for politics to occur between researchers, professors, or outside institutions. It is important to find ways to steer away from such issues so one is not affected.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: I worked as a TA so had a lot of chances to meet with students. OSU has a a diverse student and faculty background. You can practice your communication skills a lot by meeting different people. Good academics training, too. People are usually very nice.
cons: Columbus is a little bit boring. You have to bore with this. TA salary is low, but most of the time you are not busy.

pros: Flexible hours, competitive pay, good work environment and plenty of room for upward mobility.
cons: repetitive tasks and sometimes managers could be lazy about creating schedules.  Once they were created though, there was large flexibility in dropping or adding shifts, however this was not well facilitated by management.

pros: Great university and exciting culture and climate, I love living in Cbus. My PI is flexible and understanding.
cons: Delivery service is terrible, HR is breathing down my neck all of the time, and postdoctoral benefits, particularly maternity/paternity leave are severely lacking. Implementation of FLSA was very poorly handled and left a lot of postdocs very unhappy.

pros: Flexible schedule, perfect for students, easy work, yearly wage increases, good upper level management in place, employs many people from international backgrounds with English as second language
cons: Work can be repetitive and tedious at times. There are so many people working for Ohio State and the university library system that you sometimes feel like a number. Not a lot of room for advancement in this particular field.

review_title: Great place to work and also play!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros:
-Excellent Quality of research
- Very diverse campus, always something to do
- Amazing physical and outdoor recreation infrastructure
cons:
- Great disparity in GRA wages between different departments, even inside the college of Engineering!
- For an organization of its size, there is a lot of red tape and bureaucracy

job_title: Patient Access Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: I enjoy working at OSU getting to interact with patients on a daily basis and build lasting relationships with them is why I got into healthcare to begin with.
cons: Some of the while most of the PROs out weigh the cons there are still somethings I am not thrilled about within my position. PTO time is not the best, and the parking situation if you work on campus is awful.

pros: Half price tuition for up to eight semesters per dependent child. Excellent life work balance.  Flexible hours. Very good health benefits though you are encouraged to use their doctors.
cons: Not the best pay and you have to pay for your own parking. Not a lot of coordination across programs. Many people take advantage of the flexibility and slack off making it difficult to get things done.

job_title: Associate Director, Marketing in Columbus, OH
pros: cool projects happening around campus, a purposeful mission, an appealing campus atmosphere, lots of events and wellness activities, amazing benefits including tuition reimbursement
cons: every unit has a different culture, i'm lucky to be in an awesome one, but you have to learn about the specific college/campus/dept's culture before you can have a real sense of the work experience

pros: Working in my field providing essential and engaging learning experiences to graduate and undergraduate students. Still maintain strong relationships with colleagues and former students.
cons: Unsafe work environment where harassment, when reported, is ignored and verbal and physical threats that were reported were also ignored.  With no safe avenue for reporting it is a terrible place to work.

pros: OSU, depending on which area you work, has great work hour flexibility.  Free tuition for you and 1/2 off tuition for dependents is a great benefit as well.
cons: My position has a number of responsibilities and can be difficult to attend classes and complete my work duties.

pros: It helps you refresh from the actual work load of the course work that the you take during the quarter.
cons: it can be too stressful at times and the job is very demanding as far as the performance of it is concerned

job_title: Student Library Aide in Columbus, OH
pros: Training is very thorough.  Whenever you have questions you always have someone you can ask for help.  Very flexible hours for a student.  Great coworkers.
cons: Work can often get boring due to the monotonous repetition of similar questions.  During the first week of school you may answer the same "where is the bathroom?" question up to 10 times in a single hour.

pros:
Incredible bosses
Opportunities to meet awesome people both within the university and beyond
Opportunity to participate on student panels around the country
Every work day brings something new
cons: Pay is mediocre for the amount of energy the work requires, but the experiences are worth the low pay

pros: Good technology and academic resources
cons:
Instructors are hired as independent contractors each semester so no job stability, health benefits, etc.
All University services are increasingly privatized and therefore everything is becoming more expensive- for example prying costs have almost doubled since privatization.

pros: great benefits, great work life balance,good coworkers.  Really nice tuition benefits and opportunity to meet lots of great people through out the campus.Knowledgable, productive and engaged colleagues and superiors who care about their work and also the community
cons: slow pace not much cutting edge technology used. Good place for beginners and I have seen those who are more competitive and ambitious would eventually leave seeking better opportunity.

pros: Ohio State is a wonderful place to make a career.  Best retirement in town interesting work very little downsides.
cons: The top 2 percent of earners take up 80 percent of Ohio State's budget.  The income distribution is truly unjust.  If you can ignore it you'll be better off.  Advancement is the worst for this with salaries ridiucously high for a tax payers institution.

pros: Ohio State RPAC was a fantastic place to work with great colleagues and ample opportunity for learning. I'd recommend it highly!
cons: I wouldn't change anything about my experience. I was given excellent training for my role, and overall it was a great place to work.

review_title: Great experience, fun teams, and great senior management!
pros:
- Time is flexible
- Salary can be based on hourly, and some benefits like 50% of your tuition (if you decide to study in OSU)
- Great environment to work in
cons:
- Promotion seems like a fairy tale
- Doing the same thing over and over again
- no new challanges

review_title: all levels of student jobs are good
pros: The hours work around your student schedule and management is very understanding about any personal or class conflicts
cons: They are constantly trying to become more efficient so they seem to be changing things constantly, and it leads to inefficiency and occasionally bad ideas.

pros: The experience is wonderful, the employees are diversified, and the location is convenient.
cons: The hours are demanding and the management was not very interactive with the employees. The hours went along with my schooling but were so many that by the time I was done working I had little time to do anything else.

job_title: Student & Disciplinary Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Working with a large amount of people with various backgrounds.  Great for personal growth, with possibilities for communication, customer service, time management, and leadership experience.
cons: One can easily get lost in the crowd with many people working at a time in possible stressful environments.

pros: Great benefits with decent pay hours were good very flexible. Met some great doctors and nurses while working five years for them
cons: Nurse to patient ratio  was very high not a lot of help which made for an environment to make mistakes. Some managers very difficult to work with

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: It's literally the size of a small city and has all the resources you can imagine.  There's phenomenal state and community support for the university.
cons: It's so big that there are many layers of bureaucracy and it can take forever for things to happen with lots of hurdles to jump through.

review_title: It highly depends on the college/department you are working for as to whether your experience will be good or bad.
pros: Support for conference attendance/presentations, benefits are great, coworkers tend to be supportive as well.
cons: Faculty do not listen to anyone even if someone else knows more. People in leadership positions are often not knowledgeable about effective and positive leadership styles.

job_title: PGY1 Community Care Pharmacy Resident in Columbus, OH
pros: The dynamic and collaborative work environment challenges employees to develop key skills and form lasting relationships with leaders in the field of pharmacy and health care.
cons: Living amongst a campus of 40,000+ students can be overwhelming if used to a smaller community or environment. Adjusting to a larger city was a bit of a challenge for someone from a rural farming community.

pros: The benefits are very good which include free tuition for employees.
cons: The vice-provost at the time did not truly care for the populations we served. The people in charge were not concerned with training employees or helping employees advance their careers if they were not in the clique.

review_title: Student Manager Dining at Central Production Kitchen
pros: Work hours are flexible. Managers are very considerate and there's a lot of activities done to improve student's well being show they really care about their workers.
cons: If you are a student, the travel is quite far. Taking the bus from campus will take 35 mins. However, if you drive, it will be much easier.

pros: works around your class schedule and is easy to do with class work load. nice bosses and understanding.  fun staff
cons: sometimes difficult to work around classes especially if a class gets moved or canceled.. work with other students can be stressul

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: The best part of being a GRA here is the benefits. You get tuition fully-covered, and the student health benefits are much better than what I have heard of other schools in the area.
cons: The work experience and culture would heavily depend on the research group that you work with, so I can not really generalize cons here to a university level.

pros: You start out at minimum wage, which seems fair enough, but there is no upward mobility (have to work 400 hours to be considered for a promotion - difficult with student class schedule). Working with fellow students is fun, though.
cons: Management are very close-minded, need to loosen up a bit. They are very by-the-book and not open to suggestions/not overly supportive of employees.

review_title: Great Benefits. You have to be willing to work for such a LARGE employer.
pros: Great benefits and Buckeye pride.
cons: The size of the university contributes to a massive amount of bureaucracy and micro management. Not the best environment for the creative, free thinking types.

pros: Persons here are nice, team work is good. pace is not fast. Employee can register classes in university. The children tuition is 50% off.  Benefits and employer's retiring match are really good
cons: Introduction pace of  new technology is slow. no bonus, no stock option.

pros: I have been impressed by the flexibility of my schedule during my three years at the university. Free tuition is also a benefit to employees (1/2 price for employees' children), which saves thousand of dollars.
cons: The bureaucracy can be difficult to navigate -- you can get things done if you find the right person, but finding that person isn't always easy.

pros: Pay, benefits, people are nice, many fellow employees are long-time staff
cons: Changed the health benefits so you end up getting high deductible insurance if you don't participate in your plan for health, but this wasn't communicated good enough.

pros: Students are provided free room and board, you can meet many friends, and you get to make a lasting impression on students coming to Ohio State.
cons: You work all hours of the night when there are emergencies. You also must call students out for unhealthy behavior and report it to your manager for their safety. Of course, it's meritable, but not comfortable for everyone.

review_title: Definitely the most amazing experience of my professional career!
pros: The benefits are great and being able to positively impact the undergraduate student experience is a very rewarding experience. Most coworkers are passionate professionals who want to make a difference!
cons: Salary and advancement could be better! Your opportunity is viewed as a privilege that you should be grateful for, so average pay increases are about 2% per year.

pros: I learned a lot while I was there, and got a chance to put it into action.  Invaluable experience.
cons: Dealing with the graduate school can be a pain, plus loud and strange lab peers. There were more lab politics than I preferred.

job_title: Graduate Research & Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Great health benefits and perks (RPAC, COTA, etc.) forG RAs and GTAs, although you do technically pay for them through your student fees.
cons: Work-life balance is hard to maintain. Pay is laughable.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Experience teaching, UCAT availability, now commitment to year long funding (in Arts and Sciences), excellent faculty
cons: Parking is an issue, Pay is not competitive with top tier universities (OSU wants to compete with them).   Ultimately at the whim of faculty/department for continued funding.

review_title: Best places to work in Columbus
pros: The benefits, the access to services, speakers, professionals, sporting events, and amazing networking opportunities.
cons: It is difficult to get one's foot int he door, and then once it's in, you are so specialized that it can be difficult to transition outside of your own department, but certainly not impossible.

pros: Excellent benefits.  Line-level employees start off with very generous pay.  Scheduling is mostly very flexible, and it's a great community to be a part of.  Job security is very good.
cons: Management does not start off with great pay.  You will be hard-pressed to find more out-of-touch people than college professors.  However, the staff is generally good people.

pros: Great resources, great support staff, and a great institution in general. There are so many experts from every area that there are plenty of people with the expertise in any area you may need.
cons: Bureaucracy is often a pain. It can take awhile to get things done and there can be many layers to getting stuff done that you aren't even aware of.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: I can study a lot from Professors when I do the research with them. It's a great opportunity to learn about the cutting-edge technologies.
cons: It's very hard to learn some term. The work is tedious sometime which takes you a long time such as building up a model

pros: Good people, relatively easy work, not difficult to figure out. Dealing with college students, makes it relatively easy for customer service.
cons: Growing focus on enforcing nitpicky rules, and far less generosity on hourly wage increases, made for an increasingly worse experience there.

review_title: Fair, but work hard for best benefits
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros:
Decent health insurance for the cost
Great campus facilities, ie gym, library, labs
Interdisciplinary research is encouraged
Low cost of living
cons:
Undergrads are not the most motivated
Professors can get caught up in politics on things like curriculum, hiring

review_title: Good part time work for students
pros: They will work around your class schedules pretty painlessly. Allows you to make your own hours. They know that school takes the priority.
cons: Balancing work and school can be fairly stressful. The pay is not very good. Would help if there were some extra benefits like a reduction in the cost of a parking pass.

pros:
+Flexible Hours with School Work
+Good Wage for Students
+Relatively Simple Tasks with General IT Knowledge
cons:
+No Benefits (Could Pay into Government Retirement Fund)
+Somewhat Dull, but Could Browse the Web or Finish Homework

review_title: Not what it used to be.
pros: Medical Insurance. Vacation and ill time off. Available careers. Available shifts.
cons: Pay extremely low.  Way too many highly paid administrators. Many documented cases of harassment. Poorly chosen managers and supervisors. Overall elitist attitude by employer.

pros: Competitive Pay, great benefits, and Tuition Assistance.  The culture is very inclusive. Most people are happy, and great to work with.
cons: Parking, parking, and parking. Remote parking makes for a tedious trek to and from work. The annual raises leave much to be desired.

pros: Great work environment with fun coworkers and good camaraderie. Got in some good practice working engineering problems as a grader too!
cons: Happened to have a great boss, I imagine if you didn't have a great boss your experience may not be the same. But I've had SEVERAL great bosses at OSU for the different jobs I've worked there as a student.

job_title: Information Technology Student Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: My supervisors are more than willing to work with me on my schedule so that I can focus on my classes and studies. Laid back environment.
cons: There isn't anything to complain about, for a student employee position. The pay is decent and the hours are great.

pros: Loved the opportunities afforded by such a large employer. Easy to get involved in side projects and gain on-the-job professional development. Salary is commensurate with other public sector roles, benefits are above average.
cons: It's a large place - over 12,000 faculty and staff can make it challenging to navigate for folks who don't enjoy networking and "working the system".

pros: Good benefits, good facilities, easy access to games, health, dental benefits for you and family members, access to great cafeterias
cons: Underpaid. They dont value all your studies and pay very uncompetitively. I suggest you evaluate this before you decide to work here

pros:
Tuition reimbursement (up to $9,000 per semester, even grad school)
Competitive healthcare plan
Many professional development opportunities
cons:
Inept leadership (in my experience, not for everyone)
Max 2% raise per year, not much incentive to do more than you have to
Upward mobility depends on your department, not necessarily a given
Some colleges are created differently

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU has one of the best recreational facilities in the US.  Columbus city is also very family friendly.  Living on campus is fabulous for students as well as for staffs.
cons: Maybe the only one downside of working at OSU is that sometimes the traffic is congested when there is a football game or some kind of shows around.

pros: Good benefits, access to wide variety of services and products through the University.
cons: Workload is inconsistent, dependent on academic calendar and semesters. Expensive parking and gym membership.

review_title: Alot of work for a student
pros:
Good management experience
A good way to get your foot in the door for Higher Education 
 You get you to arrange your schedule and a lot of your staff's events
cons:
A lot of work for a student. I was constantly working and getting messages from OAs or my HD
Not a lot of guidance for you start the job

review_title: The management is dysfunctional, but they're flexible and allow me to balance work and schooling effectively.
pros: It is a good networking opportunity to find a diverse range of people across an array of disciplines. Flexible with my schedule.
cons: Management is meddlesome and have a lack of communication. Employee morale isn't an issue to them, and it results in some unprofessional behavior on their part.

review_title: Great place to receive graduate training.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: The department provides excellent training and support for teaching assistants, which transfers to the academic job market. Good faculty mentors, but you must seek them out.
cons: Relatively heavy teaching loads which cut into research/writing time a bit more than I'd like. However, the load is not unreasonable.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Advantage of working at a large university is the HUGE variety of opportunities presented.  Overall being a grad student at OSU has been a great experience.  The salary, while small, goes a long way in Columbus, OH.
cons: No real downsides.  Work weeks can be long (60-70 hours), but this is expected as a grad student.

pros: Really fun and relaxed atmosphere. I enjoy talking with every person I work with and I appreciate their time and effort.
cons: Really gruesome and hard work that requires you to get your hands dirty. Often had to pick up slack from other employees who just don't care enough about their on-campus job to give their full effort.

job_title: Research Associate II in Columbus, OH
pros: it is very good to work as research associate ii at OSU because it is a good place to learn and live.
cons: The  salary maybe is not high compared to company. It's also depended on the budget.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: You get to be a part of the Ohio State University system. There is a constant stream of new students which keeps things exciting. You work with a large number of extremely intelligent individuals.
cons: It can be a little stiff, culture-wise. They aren't open to taking many risks. Because OSU is so big, the wheels of bureaucracy can move slowly.

pros: Good benefits.  Competitive Stipend.  Great support staff.
cons:
-The machine shop was understaffed, which was due to budget constraints, and was unavoidable, but still unfortunate. 
-Your individual experience really depends on the group you are working with, so try to find a research group you enjoy and get along with will as early in the program as possible.

pros: It's a great university and well respected employer.  Benefits are competitive, flexible schedules are available for many positions.
cons: It can be hard for staff to advance within their departments - departments tend to not provide a clear path for promotion.  But there are always jobs available and you can advance by applying in other departments.

pros: Flexible hours; they put school first; easy to change schedule
cons: We are treated like we are unimportant just because we are student workers. It feels like we are unappreciated from time to time.

review_title: Working as a student employee, they were very flexible and understanding of my schedule.
pros: The flexibility and team oriented goals allowed for a working environment that was both professional and relaxed. The people made the job better.
cons: The lack of management of the superiors often led to employees taking advantage of them by missing deadlines, work, etc.

job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Coworkers are friendly and professional. The supervisor is very knowledgable and very supportive, that helps a lot in the academic research.
cons: Actually there are not many cons. If I have to say, it would the lab management could be better, such as the equipment usage and maintain.

pros: Schedule was pretty flexible and things were very well planned. Supervisors are pretty nice and have a great understanding.
cons: I had to grade a lot of exams which was too boring. During final exams, things became a bit hectic, otherwise it was fine.

pros: Teaching students at The Ohio State University is enjoyable. Overall they are great. Also, the material that you cover in  a course is decently solid.
cons: In general, the math department doesn't have much regard for its part-time lecturers. This is probably the case in other departments. They won't higher you full-time.They will never give you benefits, health insurance, etc.

review_title: OSU has a perfect working environment
job_title: Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Surrounded with young students, making yourself feeling that you are young. Time is flexible so that you don't have to stick to the restrict schedule.
cons: Salary is not competitive. Especially if you have a family to support. But meanwhile you may enjoy a lot of services in campus, which is more expensive outside campus.

review_title: Not a bad place to be a grad student
pros: It has competitive wages and is a top tier STEM university. There are many options to learn from world class scientists and is a phenomenal place to learn.
cons: It's in Ohio. The winters have freezing rain, Glass Door is forcing me to have a 20 word minimum I am trying to hit.

review_title: The Ohio State University is a world-class research institution with great faculty and high-quality people.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Columbus, OH
pros: Is a great university with plenty of resources. The faculty are great and the research opportunities are endless. A wonderful place to get an education and prepare for a vocation.
cons: It is a very large institution.  One can get lost in the crowd.

job_title: Associate Vice President in Columbus, OH
pros: University Setting was great.  Great facilities and lots to do.  Access to classes and amazing people.  Could explore any topic.
cons: Insane Politics with no clear direction.  Many competing interests make it almost impossible to get anything meaningful done.  Unhappiest time in my professional life.

review_title: Good pay, mostly up to your adviser
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Columbus, OH
pros: In the Physics dept., the pay is good.  Your experience is up to your adviser, so choose wisely.
cons: Not a top tier university.  Football team is probably more important that academics.

review_title: Good research environment, great networks and people
pros: There are many great professors and researchers which also helps with networking connections. The university is very supportive with funding opportunities for students. Columbus is also a great city with diverse people around.
cons: Being a "big" university, there are some rules and restrictions on administrative procedures which might be hard to find.

job_title: Psychology Lab Assistant in Marion, OH
pros:
Good benefits, even though I was part-time.
Flexible hours.
Wonderful work-study opportunity.
Helped gain experience in my future field.
cons:
There was a lack of direction--I didn't know what I was doing from day to day until I got to the lab.
I couldn't transfer jobs when I switched from a branch campus to main campus.

pros: The salary and benefits are great at Ohio State University.  Depending on the area of work, employees are provided flexibility and latitude to make the position their own.
cons: The HR function at OSU is week.  Issues are often ignored and left to fester.

pros: Great benefits and growth opportunities
cons: Nurse/patient ratio 5:1 moderate acuity.

pros: Great benefits and challenging work. You stay young by being surrounded by young college students. Still one of the few places that you can participate in an actual pension plan, this one is part of the OPERS, Ohio Public Employees Retirement System.
cons: Being a public institution, the pay is not as high as in the private sector.

pros: Great people to work with. Dining services good means to have a small part time job. Good food in the cafeteria . One time food benefits during shifts.
cons: Length hours... miniumum shift of 5 hrs. Can become tiring. Should know how to manage shifts. Only minimum pay jobs available for starters.

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Great teamwork on floor, good management and helpful environment. Good benefits and wonderful upper management.
cons: Patient Load can be very heavy sometimes, and shifts are physically exhausting. Lots of heavy lifting involved.

job_title: Registered Dental Hygienist in Columbus, OH
pros: The benefits provided by and available at OSU are terrific. After three years of employment, an individual is even eligible to purchase season tickets for OSU football. OSU Health Plan membership gives the employee access to many health and wellness activities designed to help the individual achieve his/her optimum health.
cons: Parking at the main campus including cost.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: I am a graduate student at OSU and work as research associate.  The are no set hours for research associates and therefore you get to work at a pace that's suitable for you and independent is highly encouraged, though obviously this varies by advisor.
cons: Though GRA-ship is a half time appointment, you will definitely work longer hours.

pros: Very supportive staffs and work enviwonments. Especially, faculty members are pretty nice and try to help me to adopt the new environment.
cons: Hard to find a con. The only con is that students go mad when they have a football game on Saturday, but other than that this place is pretty good to work and to live.

pros: Work-life balance can be really good for staff. If you want to continue your education, it is at a very low cost, which is a huge benefit.
cons: Promotions can be hard to come by if you are doing well at your job. It seems easier if they want to get rid of you in that position.

job_title: Maintenance Repair Worker II in Columbus, OH
pros: Good benefits, good management chance to do and learn a lot. paying in to defined benefit retirement
cons: Union, it stifles personal growth and keeps the lazy people.  Parking fees are very expensive especially for non salary employees.

review_title: Was a student there, can be whole lot different when you're an employee.
pros: Big school with lots of resources. You can find a whole spectrum of careers you want to pursue.
cons: Really depends on the team you work with. Not much career advises were provided.

pros: One of the premier research universities in the world with massive resources and departments representing almost all fields.
cons: Multiple campuses/branches across the state, advancement can be dependent on degrees and not just years experience.

review_title: Thoroughly enjoyed working for the Physics department
pros: The tutoring hours were flexible. I was given full control over how I wanted to teach. There was very little structure and it was super relaxed. I really liked how this program was run.
